story:
I have spent, most likely, several thousand hours skulking around the country, acting mostly as indie-music documentarian–but, sometimes co-conspirator–with Noah Engh, in numerous automobiles, sleeping in only the finest one-star hotels, drinking only the finest bottom-shelf swill for the economically minded romantics among us. There have been a lot of late nights, obscenely early mornings, amazing shows, porches and patios, bloodshed, and financial destitution.

From, and because of the numerous tours came many music videos, documentary films, thousands of photos, and countless miles of the finest scenery man can conjur–so long as he’s conjuring that scenery, usually, along the I-10 corridor between Houston, Texas, through the desert southwest, and straight through Hollywood to where the water meets the land.

The images in this book are a collection of mostly impromptu, or very loosely planned portraits culled from my first four years of working and traveling with Noah throughout the American southwest. No client or subject has ever given me as much free reign as Noah, In fact, Noah has never once refused a portrait, pose, or journey to get the right image (though he did make known his disdain for the shot where he is dragging seaweed from the ocean, and ultimately ended up with a shredded, bloody hand because of it). This is highly unique, considering that independent musicians are typically unreasonably guarded in regard to every detail of their image.

As a result of Noah's unique willingness to succumb to so many unplanned, sporadic photoshoots over so many years, I've ended up with an astonishing collection of portraits far beyond what is ever expected to be seen of so-called "unknown" musicians.


Some of these photos have been used on a handful of concert posters, a few have been included in some of the album art I have also designed for Noah and his full-band projects. Others have appeared briefly in the forgettable fog of social media, but many have not yet been seen in any visual arena.

The goal of this campaign is not to trumpet the horn of any cause, or subculture. There is no reason why you should care about Noah Engh other than he looks good in a photo, and he's a great musician who many of you may already appreciate. The goal of this campaign is to release an excellent collection of portraits of a musician.

Most musicians–famous, and lauded by mainstream (or extensive cult followings), or unkowns and neverwas'–will never have an extended subject/artist relationship, or anthalogy of portraits in the realm of those created by relationships with artists such as Anton Corbijn or Annie Leibovitz. While I might never be recognized as such a prolific artist as Corbijn (maybe I will, what do you think of that?), I have always recognized my opportunity with, and body of work that has resulted from my relationship with many musicians as something far deeper than that which typically exists in the indie arena. Noah is a prime example of this.


While it is a great thrill to think of a nice, bookstore quality book of my own publishing sitting idly on my bookshelf to be shared with sporadic visitors to my domicile, I am more intrigued by the notion that, together, we can support and respect truly independent artists and musicians with a handsome collection of visual work that typically eludes even the most established mainstream musicians.

Still have questions? Let's explore your deep concerns.

So, what, is this like a little pamphlet or something?

No, certainly not! This is a high quality soft-cover "coffee table book." As it stands now, the version set for print will be 7"x7" with a minimum of 80 pages. Yeah, I know. Kinda small... but, pretty big.


To where is your money flowing?

Super question, of course. Your accountant must be proud! Unfortunately for me, there's nothing from this campaign that is nestling itself into any corner of my pocket. All of the money raised will be quickly, and completely absorbed by the printing and shipping costs. The book is completely prepared, laid out, and ready for print. Your pledge simply ensures that your copy is one to be included in this first edition run.


What if I don't meet my goal?

It's okay. We all know this isn't going to be flying off the shelves of the remaining Barnes & Noble's, or being zipped around warehouses in the clutches of robot hands, by the thousands, on it's way to every mail-room at Amazon. There will be a very limited run of books one way or another. This campaign simply ensures that the first edition run satisfies the demand, rewards those who have supported and followed the work of both Noah and myself over the years, and will appreciate an opportunity to have a unique, high quality publication that not only satisfies the eye, but directly supports the artists and publication itself. For those who have stumbled across this project randomly, and have been compelled to support it simply on flabbergastory and intrigue? Congratulations. You're part of this now. Dive in and stay in touch. We want you.


What about this hubcap?

For the filming of my 2011 documentary film about Noah Engh and the real story of his life on the road, 330 shows per year, as a solo, DIY touring musician, we obtained a 1972 Cadillac Eldorado. Many of Noah's songs mention Cadillacs, or classic cars, and we felt that the otherwise mundane day-to-day of a DIY touring rockstar would be made ever more interesting by staging the filming of a west-coast tour of the United States from behind the facade of a worn, vintage Cadillac. We were right in our attempt, but we blew up the engine less than two hours into our month-long journey from Phoenix, to San Diego, all the way north to Seattle, and back through Reno and Las Vegas to central Arizona. None of it was staged, and we unintentionally charred a lot of bridges in the process, but it made for a good portion of film. We eventually received recognition on "My Caddy Won't Let Me" with inclusion to numerous film festivals, including the prestigious "Short Documentary Film" program at the 2012 Phoenix Film Festival, where I was also honored to be invited as a featured panelist on their "Independent Film Roundtable". By pledging your money and good name to this hubcap, book, and poster package–it's true!–you are dedicating your support to the art far more than any profit of the artist. Plus, it's a vintage automobile hubcap! An enjoyable, simple appreciation of classic American automotive design and history with an interesting back-story. Also, these original hubcaps fetch some decent cash on the open market. Just sayin'! Who knows, maybe your indie-rockumentary film hubcap will someday send your eldest to stenographer school!


Who exactly am I, and how do you know I'm legit?

Uhhhh, duh! I have a website! Only legit players skunk around on "the net", y'know. In fact, for the past decade I have been a professional video producer. While the majority of my work has typically been commercial promotional projects, I have had the unusual opportunity to explore and fulfill a vast number of "cool projects": documentary films; touring with, and photographing rock bands throughout the United States and Europe; lots of album art and graphic design (from which there may be another book, and/or gallery showing, stay tuned); and tons of music videos. There have been lots of musicians, and lots of photos over the years, but this volume culled from my work with Noah is unique both in it's depth, but also it's focus. When shooting photos of independent musicians you always end up with lots of very "typical" shots of bands performing in very uninteresting places. It is far more difficult to get a legitimately good opportunity to take even a marginally decent portrait of an independent musician, or band (for a lot of reasons I won't go into at this time) let alone the chance to create a volume of work showcasing one particular subject over both land and time that would be worth even a personal retrospective on your laptop, cold, and alone in your basement. In the case of my relationship with Noah, while I've been to a lot of his shows, I have very few photos of him performing live. This is because I was usually covering those performances for documentary film coverage, shooting video instead of stills. Instead, because we covered so much actual geographic ground creating the film footage–driving through, and killing down-time in the lost corners of America's west, between Houston and San Diego, all the way up to Seattle and back down to Phoenix–the photos I did get were almost all portraits nestled in the impromptu cruck of hot, welcoming desolation. Often, the goal of a photoshoot itself was known, but the destination was not: "I know of a dirt road in these mountains, let's just drive up there for some photos on our way to Los Angeles." The result is what you will find here in this gorgeous book that you will cherish until the day your soul and body divorce, and you merge with the infinite.


Okay, seems legit. When do you get your book?

As soon as humanly possible. Upon the closing of the IndieGoGo campaign, I will make any final adjustments to the book layout for print (which is already essentially ready for print) and send the files and payment to the printer. Simple as that. Upon receiving the completed books from the printer, we will schedule a session for Noah and I to do the book signings (and numbering) in a convenient location–he lives in LA, I live in Phoenix, which probably means we'll sign your books in the bosom of the ghost of the desert outside of Joshua Tree. We'll jam pack the boxes and dump them off with the parcel carrier immediately thereafter. The assumption is that all of this can be buttoned up within approximately one month of sending the book to the printer.

How many books will be included in the limited first print?

You tell me. The pre-order limit in this campaign is capped at 68 total books. We will likely push the initial order a little beyond what we need to satisfy the orders from this campaign so we have a few extras to show as examples. Bare minimum: probably 10. Maximum: up to 75. Still an elite club, no matter how you cut it. Make yourself a part of the 1% (of indie-music art aficionados!)


What are any challenges or roadblocks concerning the completion of this project?

Actually, there are no real roadblocks. However, printing niche art books in small volumes is expensive. The fulfillment of this campaign will allow me to tailor the first-edition print order to satisfy the immediate demand without exhausting my own bank account. Any challenge associated with this book might be, simply, the promise of delivering the final product on a certain day. My estimate is that the book could be delivered sometime in December 2015. Between print and delivery to me, then scheduling a time for hand-signing and numbering the books, and finally sending them out for delivery, there could be a variable of up to a few weeks. Can we get it to you by the end of December? Yes, possibly. Could it potentially be sometime in January if a few speed-bumps pop up? Sure. I will keep all backers updated through the entire process. Frankly, I would like to do a live-stream (Periscope, UStream, etc.) of the book signing and packaging for maximum engagement, if possible! Show your support, and it will happen!

We all know this isn't going to be flying off the shelves of the remaining Barnes & Noble's, or being zipped around warehouses in the clutches of robot hands, by the thousands, on it's way to every mail-room at Amazon. There will be a very limited run of books one way or another. This campaign simply ensures that the first edition run satisfies the demand, rewards those who have supported and followed the work of both Noah and myself over the years, and will appreciate an opportunity to have a unique, high quality publication that not only satisfies the eye, but directly supports the artists and publication itself. For those who have stumbled across this project randomly, and have been compelled to support it simply on flabbergastory and intrigue? Congratulations. You're part of this now. Dive in and stay in touch. We want you.What about this hubcap?For the filming of my 2011 documentary film about Noah Engh and the real story of his life on the road, 330 shows per year, as a solo, DIY touring musician, we obtained a 1972 Cadillac Eldorado. Many of Noah's songs mention Cadillacs, or classic cars, and we felt that the otherwise mundane day-to-day of a DIY touring rockstar would be made ever more interesting by staging the filming of a west-coast tour of the United States from behind the facade of a worn, vintage Cadillac. We were right in our attempt, but we blew up the engine less than two hours into our month-long journey from Phoenix, to San Diego, all the way north to Seattle, and back through Reno and Las Vegas to central Arizona. None of it was staged, and we unintentionally charred a lot of bridges in the process, but it made for a good portion of film. We eventually received recognition on "My Caddy Won't Let Me" with inclusion to numerous film festivals, including the prestigious "Short Documentary Film" program at the 2012 Phoenix Film Festival, where I was also honored to be invited as a featured panelist on their "Independent Film Roundtable". By pledging your money and good name to this hubcap, book, and poster package–it's true!–you are dedicating your support to the art far more than any profit of the artist. Plus, it's a vintage automobile hubcap! An enjoyable, simple appreciation of classic American automotive design and history with an interesting back-story. Also, these original hubcaps fetch some decent cash on the open market. Just sayin'! Who knows, maybe your indie-rockumentary film hubcap will someday send your eldest to stenographer school!Who exactly am I, and how do you know I'm legit?Uhhhh, duh! I have a website! Only legit players skunk around on "the net", y'know. In fact, for the past decade I have been a professional video producer. While the majority of my work has typically been commercial promotional projects, I have had the unusual opportunity to explore and fulfill a vast number of "cool projects": documentary films; touring with, and photographing rock bands throughout the United States and Europe; lots of album art and graphic design (from which there may be another book, and/or gallery showing, stay tuned); and tons of music videos. There have been lots of musicians, and lots of photos over the years, but this volume culled from my work with Noah is unique both in it's depth, but also it's focus. When shooting photos of independent musicians you always end up with lots of very "typical" shots of bands performing in very uninteresting places. It is far more difficult to get a legitimately good opportunity to take even a marginally decent portrait of an independent musician, or band (for a lot of reasons I won't go into at this time) let alone the chance to create a volume of work showcasing one particular subject over both land and time that would be worth even a personal retrospective on your laptop, cold, and alone in your basement. In the case of my relationship with Noah, while I've been to a lot of his shows, I have very few photos of him performing live. This is because I was usually covering those performances for documentary film coverage, shooting video instead of stills. Instead, because we covered so much actual geographic ground creating the film footage–driving through, and killing down-time in the lost corners of America's west, between Houston and San Diego, all the way up to Seattle and back down to Phoenix–the photos I did get were almost all portraits nestled in the impromptu cruck of hot, welcoming desolation. Often, the goal of a photoshoot itself was known, but the destination was not: "I know of a dirt road in these mountains, let's just drive up there for some photos on our way to Los Angeles." The result is what you will find here in this gorgeous book that you will cherish until the day your soul and body divorce, and you merge with the infinite.Okay, seems legit. When do you get your book?As soon as humanly possible. Upon the closing of the IndieGoGo campaign, I will make any final adjustments to the book layout for print (which is already essentially ready for print) and send the files and payment to the printer. Simple as that. Upon receiving the completed books from the printer, we will schedule a session for Noah and I to do the book signings (and numbering) in a convenient location–he lives in LA, I live in Phoenix, which probably means we'll sign your books in the bosom of the ghost of the desert outside of Joshua Tree. We'll jam pack the boxes and dump them off with the parcel carrier immediately thereafter. The assumption is that all of this can be buttoned up within approximately one month of sending the book to the printer.How many books will be included in the limited first print?You tell me. The pre-order limit in this campaign is capped at 68 total books. We will likely push the initial order a little beyond what we need to satisfy the orders from this campaign so we have a few extras to show as examples. Bare minimum: probably 10. Maximum: up to 75. Still an elite club, no matter how you cut it. Make yourself a part of the 1% (of indie-music art aficionados!)What are any challenges or roadblocks concerning the completion of this project?Actually, there are no real roadblocks. However, printing niche art books in small volumes is expensive. The fulfillment of this campaign will allow me to tailor the first-edition print order to satisfy the immediate demand without exhausting my own bank account. Any challenge associated with this book might be, simply, the promise of delivering the final product on a certain day. My estimate is that the book could be delivered sometime in December 2015. Between print and delivery to me, then scheduling a time for hand-signing and numbering the books, and finally sending them out for delivery, there could be a variable of up to a few weeks. Can we get it to you by the end of December? Yes, possibly. Could it potentially be sometime in January if a few speed-bumps pop up? Sure. I will keep all backers updated through the entire process. Frankly, I would like to do a live-stream (Periscope, UStream, etc.) of the book signing and packaging for maximum engagement, if possible! Show your support, and it will happen!

story:
Prism Photography Exhibition

Hey everyone, we are The University of Guelph-Humber's graduating Image Arts Class. 

We have worked extremely hard for the last four years to learn photographic techniques and develop our photographic styles in anticipation for our final art exhibit. The time has finally come for us to showcase all of our hard work in the beautiful Arta Gallery in Toronto's Distillery District. It is an honour to have the opportunity to unveil our photography to all of our friends, family and general public.


What We Need & What You Get

We were fortunate enough to receive a budget from our school however we quickly learned that in order to provide our guests with the best experience possible, we could use a few extra dollars. The majority of the money donated will go towards the opening reception, allowing us to serve food and beverages in order to provide guests with a memorable experience.

Heres what we'll do for you! We appreciate all donations and each denomination will get you a little perk. Donating could get you the biggest high-five or the chance to walk away with your very own slice of Prism with a framed print of your choice.

Other Ways You Can Lend A Hand

Help us spread the word! As "starving artists" we understand that money can be tight and although we appreciate any donation, you can help us in other ways too. Sharing this campaign will help garner attention for our project and make for a successful opening reception. 

Donation or no donation, your attendance and support means the world to us, so please come out and help us celebrate all our hard work.

story:
When someone asks you to teach them English, you don't hand them a dictionary and tell them to learn all the words first, so why should learning photography be any different? At Primary Photo Education we feel that learning photography shouldn't involve months of classroom lecture and theory, but instead be a hands on and interactive experience between you, your gear and some of the best instructors in the business. We currently offer customizable one-on-one photo classes where our customers pick the time, subject, and even the location of their convenience, but we want to do more!  

We would like to offer group workshops that cover specific types of photography, but without sacrificing our hands-on approach.  These workshops would take the form of shooting a soccer game right from the sidelines or learning to capture star trails next to a calm lake.  We may even go so far as to stage an entire wedding just so our students get the experience we feel they deserve!  In these workshops, the student will receive invaluable tips, and hands-on experience from some of the best photographers in the business, but that's not the end of it.  We also plan to provide industry standard and professionally proffered equipment such as lenses and lighting to help our students make the right choices in their gear.

So what do we need your help for? Most of the donations will go toward "class materials" like the lenses and lighting we mentioned. These may be rentals or purchases, whatever ends up being more equitable. Significant amounts will also go toward renting classroom space when we need it. We will also be purchasing computers and a high-end projector and screen.  Whatever funds are left will go into our website and some hot advertising.

Like we said before, we've been doing this for a while and have already jumped most of the hurdles that new ventures run into.  With over 10 years of combined experience in teaching photography, we don't see providing well thought out and informative workshops as being a problem. There are, however, a few variables that haven't been present before. For example, what if we offer a class in a remote location and there are no classroom spaces for rent near by? What if we can't find any teams willing to work with us on our action/sports seminars? Or worse, what if we can't get enough butts in seats to cover our expenses?

We've been thinking about these issues for a while and have come up with a few creative solutions that we think may prevent them from cropping up.  Like purchasing folding chairs and a large outdoor canopy to hold the introduction and presentation portions of our workshops when we find ourselves in a remote location. If we can't get any sports teams to allow us to shoot them from the sidelines, we'll offer them a CD of some photos from the class to be used as free and unlimited promotional material.  As for filling the seats, we plan to aggressively promote our first few workshops with services like Living Social, Groupon, Merc Perks, Perks.com, Tippr, paper ads, word of mouth and any others we become aware of. As soon as we see how classes are filling and which services are providing the best coverage we will scale back accordingly, after all we don't want to alienate potential new students by "always selling out too quickly"...A challenge that wouldn't upset us one bit!

We're busting with ideas for workshops and cant wait to start developing them so HURRY UP AND CLICK PLEDGE...It'll make you smarter.

story:
My name is Katlyn and I am currently a freelance photographer in a small town near Youngstown, Ohio. Around the age of twelve I decided I wanted to be a photographer and three years later, I purchased the Canon T4I. My goal is to get more involved with the community and take part in local charities and capture what's going on in our town. As of now, I am a sophomore in high school and already have what I want to do in life figured out. Lately, I have come to the realization that I cannot carry on just with what came in the box last summer. Photography is a broad subject and it is a subject I plan to explore the next two years and into college with it. By helping me raise this money, it will help support the goals I want to take part in with the community, help those also interested in photography getting hands on with working with people on the job, booking, editing and printing. I'm very set on working towards this goal and also helping others around, knowing that I'm young and know what I want. I'd be really happy to help others and assure them that their goals and dreams are not impossible no matter how young they are. We are the future.

Alone, your support means the world to me. Though, in return to the contributors, I will write a letter to everyone who contributes. Those who donate $25+ will receive a letter and a hand made candy striped bracelet. Those who contribute $75+ will receive the letter, bracelet and a $25 Starbucks giftcard! If the goal isn't reached, the money will still be put into a separate bank account specifically for photography equipment and supplies.

The reason I am doing this is because I want to express my view of the world to a wider and eye opening angle. I enjoy creating things more than anything and putting a story or emotion into a photo is what I strongly enjoy because it's challenging. The ideas I have for some photos are photos that I want to express how I see life and want to share that with others and possibly inspire them. Life is viewed differently through everyones eyes and it is truly interesting to see what others see. Though, I have business cards posted in local shoppes and restauarants, I want to expand my photography and hope to inspire others to reach their dreams, no matter what stands in the way.

If you cannot contribute, that is 100% okay. You can also help by clicking the button that sends to your social network or simply telling others about this compaign. Any bit helps and goes a long way to me. Help spread the word!

To view work, visit http://katlynjackson.com/ or Facebook https://www.facebook.com/pages/Katlyn-Jacksons-Photography/145711295474662?ref=hl

story:
Be part of FotoMarket, the first ever crowdfunded photobook store!

We at Fotografia love photobooks. Whether big or small, beautifully printed or photocopied, simply designed or stressing the book format, a satisfying photobook is a satisfying experience – just like a good album or movie is.

We've created this campaign to launch FotoMarket, an online photobook store through which we set out to bring you a curated selection of photobooks from the best publishers out there (you know who – Aperture, MACK, Self Publish Be Happy, Morel Books, etc.). We'd be thrilled to make FotoMarket come true with the help of the global community of photobook makers and lovers! 


Get your work reviewed by a pro! 

In addition to photobook credit, we're happy to announce that we've invited Salvatore Vitale to review your work! Salvatore is the editor-in-chief at YET Magazine – one of the best photo magazines out there. After claiming your review through this page, send your photographic project via email (please put Portfolio Review in the subject); the project should include at least 10 images, sized at 1440px on the long side. Once the campaign is closed we will send you back Salvatore's written review of your work! Please note that we're only accepting photographic series in this case, and not portfolios of single images (Got questions? Get in touch!). The best portfolio will be featured in Fotografia and shared across our social media!


Photobook Credit!

You might think actual photobooks would have made more sense to offer as a reward for your contributions, but the cost of buying and shipping the books would eat away at the money raised through the campaign. So we're offering photobook credit instead! In particular, the first 50 to contribute €50 will get as much credit to spend in photobooks within a year from the day FotoMarket launches; a beautiful set of photographic postcards we've designed specifically for this campaign (more on this below); and a 10% discount on all photobooks bought from FotoMarket, valid forever! By contributing €30, you get a €30 credit to spend within a year from the day FotoMarket launches.


Not interested in photobooks or reviews?

If you've been enjoying the photography we share at Fotografia and find value in the resources we offer for free – like the monthly FotoCal and our huge lists of photography grants and awards – please consider donating even if you're not interested in photobooks: FotoMarket is how we aim to support Fotografia in the future!

For you, we've created a special gift: a fantastic set of nine photographic postcards made from nine of our favorite pictures among those featured in Fotografia over the years – the full set is yours for just €30! All postcards are digitally printed and 20x15cm (8x6'') in size, and we might be biased here but they are really beautiful – you should definitely get your hands on them!


Thank you! / 1

We'd like to thank you in advance for your contribution and for following Fotografia – our work wouldn't make sense without you! 

Thank you! / 2

We'd also like to thank the nine talented photographers who shot the nine beautiful photographs we made into postcards:  Anais Boileau, Emanuele Camerini, Simon Deadman, Martin Essl, Gianfranco Gallucci, Troy Holden, Heikki Kaski, Petros Koublis, Julien Lombardi and Christoph Soeder. Thank you so much guys! 

A quick note

The photobooks presented in the campaign's video are there simply for illustrative purposes – they won't necessarily be in stock once FotoMarket launches. The images were sourced from the respective photographers or publishers and previously appeared in Fotografia. In order of appearance: Walpurg by Alíz Veronika Ács; Songbook by Alec Soth; Block by Aapo Huhta; Metropole by Lewis Bush; Besides Faith by Louis De Belle; Missing Buildings by Thom and Beth Atkinson; Lago by Ron Jude; For Birds' Sake by Maria Sturm and Cemre Yesil; Ordinary Issue I by Max Siedentopf and Yuki Kappes; Dalston Anatomy by Lorenzo Vitturi; Outland by Roger Ballen; Sense of Water by Susanna Majuri; County Jail by Charlie Kwai; We Are Leeds by Tim Morris; A DIY Photobook Manual and Manifesto by Bruno Ceschel; Halfway by Patryk Karbowski; JMZ by Arseni Khamzin.

story:
Going to Chernobyl to do some photography.

Why?

That's a good question, with a quite long answer.

First off: my name is Kimberly van Overmeeren, I'm from The Netherlands. I'm 25 years old.

The story goes like this: a few years ago, back in 2005, I went from high-school to a photography College. It was something I always knew I wanted to do. But during the first year, my dad had to undergo serious heart-surgery due to a genetic disorder on his heart.

This turned my life upside down, he wasn't able to work for quite a long time, that while my college was costing a lot of money. I was so conflicted; should I continue while I know how hard it is for my parents to pay for the school? My dad wouldn't hear of it. He wanted me to finish so badly, so I did. The second year he had to undergo another surgery. Alltogether, it was hard times while I was at college.

I did finish though, my parents were so proud. After graduating, I wanted to do a nice photographic project to really go all out on, no distractions, a special project that would really require total dedication and a lot of effort.

So I graduated, and I started my own company to be a freelance photographer. I started preparing for a trip, but something came up that just stopped everything.

My dad died on november 24th 2009.

My desire to photograph anything was totally gone, I didn't feel like grabbing my camera whatsoever. A couple of years later, early 2012, I found myself again, loving photography. And I started planning my project further. This time, with more dedication then ever. My dad did so much just to see me graduate. It's only right that I prove to him (and myself) that it was not for nothing.

This one is just not for myself anymore. It's for my dad too. This is why I want to spread it around as much as possible; at least half of the credit and the shine goes to my dad. This is my way of thanking him for everything.

I keep track of everything on my website http://www.project-tsjernobyl.nl
Click on the Union Jack, and you'll see everything in English!

This is the newspaper article done about the project, here in the Netherlands!

What We Need & What You Get

The trip is planned for May 2014, I still have some preparations to do before we can go. It is not my intention to fund the entire trip with Indiegogo, I already did that with my own money. I do want to sell the book to people all around the world.
A good friend of mine is going to design a professional book, to showcase a selection of the best photographs from the tour. I'll sell all the perks for costing price + international shipping. I'd love to see it going around the world. 


I'm not doing this project to make a big profit off the books or anything, it's not gonna earn me any money. Instead, it's going to earn me fullfillment and joy, doing what I love most; photography. I do need some funds in advance to get it printed, because I just can´t front all the money myself, buying 150 books, not knowing who will buy or not buy the book.

My goal isn´t that much; it's only 500 euro's. If only one person buys a book, it will already be a succes.
I'll also be adding some more perks along the way; from launch you can choose between a softcover of hardcover book or a poster of a photo later to choose.

I am thinking about adding a Fine Art Baryte print to it later on, I just have to check on prices and possibilites!

The Impact

Two dutch newspapers already covered the project, and I couldn't be more excited. My eyes keep tearing up thinking about how cool my dad would think this is. I already got so much good reactions from not only friends and family, but also strangers that recognized me from the paper, just wanting to wish me good luck.

My dedication will be 100% from start to finish. I learned Russian to interact with the people there and to read the signs etc. To get a little further in-depth. I already put in around €1.500 of my own money and that's not the end of it. I can't wait to go.


Other Ways You Can Help

I'll understand if you can't pledge, money can be tight! But if you do want to help, help spread the website to as many people as you can! http://www.project-tsjernobyl.nl
story_txt:
Going to Chernobyl to do some photography. 

Why?That's a good question, with a quite long answer.First off: my name is Kimberly van Overmeeren, I'm from The Netherlands. I'm 25 years old.The story goes like this: a few years ago, back in 2005, I went from high-school to a photography College. It was something I always knew I wanted to do. But during the first year, my dad had to undergo serious heart-surgery due to a genetic disorder on his heart. This turned my life upside down, he wasn't able to work for quite a long time, that while my college was costing a lot of money. I was so conflicted; should I continue while I know how hard it is for my parents to pay for the school? My dad wouldn't hear of it. He wanted me to finish so badly, so I did. The second year he had to undergo another surgery. Alltogether, it was hard times while I was at college. I did finish though, my parents were so proud. After graduating, I wanted to do a nice photographic project to really go all out on, no distractions, a special project that would really require total dedication and a lot of effort. So I graduated, and I started my own company to be a freelance photographer. I started preparing for a trip, but something came up that just stopped everything. My dad died on november 24th 2009. My desire to photograph anything was totally gone, I didn't feel like grabbing my camera whatsoever. A couple of years later, early 2012, I found myself again, loving photography. And I started planning my project further. This time, with more dedication then ever. My dad did so much just to see me graduate. It's only right that I prove to him (and myself) that it was not for nothing.This one is just not for myself anymore. It's for my dad too. This is why I want to spread it around as much as possible; at least half of the credit and the shine goes to my dad. This is my way of thanking him for everything.I keep track of everything on my website http://www.project-tsjernobyl.nlClick on the Union Jack, and you'll see everything in English!
This is the newspaper article done about the project, here in the Netherlands!


What We Need & What You Get
The trip is planned for May 2014, I still have some preparations to do before we can go. It is not my intention to fund the entire trip with Indiegogo, I already did that with my own money. I do want to sell the book to people all around the world.A good friend of mine is going to design a professional book, to showcase a selection
 of the best photographs from the tour. I'll sell all the perks for costing price
 + international shipping. I'd love to see it going around the world. 

I'm not doing this project to make a big profit off the books or anything, it's not gonna earn me any money. Instead, it's going
 to earn me fullfillment and joy, doing what I love most; photography. I do need some funds in advance to get it printed, because I just can´t front all the money myself, buying 150 books, not knowing who will buy or not buy the book.
My goal isn´t that much; it's only 500 euro's. If only one person buys a book, it will already be a succes.I'll also be adding some more perks along the way; from launch you can choose between a softcover of hardcover book or a poster of a photo later to choose. 
I am thinking about adding a Fine Art Baryte print to it later on, I just have to check on prices and possibilites!


The Impact

Two dutch newspapers already covered the project, and I couldn't be more excited. My eyes keep tearing up thinking about how cool my dad would think this is. I already got so much good reactions from not only friends and family, but also strangers that recognized me from the paper, just wanting to wish me good luck.My dedication will be 100% from start to finish. I learned Russian to interact with the people there and to read the signs etc. To get a little further in-depth. I already put in around €1.500 of my own money and that's not the end of it. I can't wait to go.



Other Ways You Can HelpI'll understand if you can't pledge, money can be tight! But if you do want to help, help spread the website to as many people as you can! http://www.project-tsjernobyl.nl

story:
My Story

My name is Mica McCook, and I'm a photographer residing in Austin, Texas. I'm seeking help to acquire a professional SLR camera. I provide professional-quality photos to low-income families, individuals and struggling local musicians. Although I launched my business with my trusty Canon Powershot camera, now it’s time to take my photography to the next level. With a new and improved camera, I will be able to shoot in all conditions and to offer the highest quality images to you.

Your Love

Your contribution will help low-income families, and struggling artists. Even a pledge of $1 will help me grow my business and achieve my dream of providing highly creative and extremely affordable photos to my clients. Portraits are important for all of us to have and to share. I would like to offer this service to those who need it the most. I know I have the vision and the passion to help others, but I just need help with the last step of getting the Canon SLR camera.

What I need and what you get

If I reach my campaign goal of $1,500, I'll be able to purchase a Canon 70D SLR camera. If I surpass this goal, then a percentage of the extra money raised will go to a local Austin charity. In return for your generous contribution, you'll get some amazing rewards such as handmade canvas prints and photo sessions with me!

Other Ways You Can Help

I get it: times are tough. If you want to support my campaign but don't have the funds to do so, here are some other ways you can help:

  • Join my team! Help spread the word about my campaign by sharing it on Facebook, Twitter, or any other social media platform! If someone you refer backs my campaign, you will get a reward as well!
  • You can donate photography equipment such as props, backdrops, furniture, etc. Please contact me for more details.

Thank you in advance for your time and contribution!

story:
Spreading Pixel Dust on the East Coast Lighthouses

Thank you for visiting my project!

Heather Hummel is a land and seascape photographer who is setting out to photograph the east coast lighthouses starting in the northern coast of Maine and traveling to the southern tip of Florida. 

She has been a photographer since high school where her favorite two classes were oceanography and photography. This is back when photographers used darkrooms with trays, fixer, developer, and stop bath!

Her work has been on exhibit in galleries from Colorado to Virginia to the Chelsea District of New York City. Now she wants to take it on the road up and down the east coast photographing lighthouses!

Jupiter, FL Lighthouse, Captured by Heather Hummel Photography

Additionally, Heather has been a ghostwriter for the past decade, penning books for public figures, corporations, therapists, entrepreneurs, real estate agents, and more. This time, she wants to tell the story of these magnificent lighthouses through the lenses of my camera. She will be documenting the lighthouses' stories by posting updates as a featured blogger (unpaid position) on the Huffington Post.

Old Point Comfort Lighthouse, located on the grounds of Fort Monroe, and captured by Heather Hummel Photography


The East Coast Lighthouses

From Maine to Florida, there are hundreds of lighthouses! The map above was sent to Heather by her brother. It shows all of the lighthouses in the southeast, which is where she started capturing some of them, including:
Jupiter, Florida
St. Augustine, Florida
St. Simons Island, Georgia
Mathews, Virginia
Hampton, Virginia

These locations are just a few she has photographed. With your help, Heather can continue the journey and introduce you to all of the east coast lighthouses through the lens of her camera.

What You Get in Return

As a contributor to the project you will be rewarded with:

$5 - A Heartfelt Thank You!

$15 - A personalized postcard from the road.

$50 - A personalized postcard from the road and a 5x7 print of one of the lighthouses.

$75 - A personalized postcard from the road and an 8x12 print of one of the lighthouses.

$100 - A personalized postcard from the road and a 16x20 print of one of the lighthouses.

$150 - A personalized postcard from the road and an 8x12 canvas wrapped print of one of the lighthouses.

$250 - A personalized postcard from the road and a 16x20 canvas wrapped print of one of the lighthouses.

$500 - A personalized postcard from the road and a 16x20 matted and framed print of one of the lighthouses.

St. Augustine, FL Lighthouse, captured by Heather Hummel Photography

Where Does the Money Go?

The funds for the project will go to:

  • Travel expenses to include gas, food, and lodging. The entire east coast is a lot to cover, so most of the money will go toward traveling to the lighthouses.
  • Gear! Heather will need to upgrade some of her camera gear, add a wide angle lens, and add some filters to the mix.


    • Old Point Comfort Lighthouse, located on the grounds of Fort Monroe, and captured by Heather Hummel Photography

The Impact

The purpose of this project is to:

  • Share the stories and images behind these lighthouses with the masses.
  • Heather has photographed the California coast, the Rocky Mountains, and the Blue Ridge Mountains - this project is near and dear to her because it takes her back to her New England roots and down the coast rather than cross country.
  • Others will learn about the history of these magnificent lighthouses through the lenses of her camera.
  • She will document the journey via my blog on the Huffington Post.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Heather is most grateful to those who help to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign. Simply use the Share tools!

Be sure to check out the "Gallery" tab that showcase Heather's photography from California to Colorado to the East Coast.

Visit her website at www.HeatherHummelPhotography.com for more examples. 

Thank you for contributing and/or sharing! <3

story:
A WEEK OF SHOOTS AT THE SALTON SEA!

Each day has a different theme, each day is limited in number of people i will be shooting.


Angel Donors- $300 an you get a 2 hour shoot at the Salton Sea on April 27th!

I am trying something new. 7 days at the Salton Sea. I want to invite people in these categories (pin-up, circus, nude, magicians, mermaids, bellydancers, etc...) to come and play with me on certain days, and bring a flashdrive so they can take home the black and white images that very day. Color images would follow in about 6 weeks.

To offset costs I am asking strangers to give me money because they like my work and don't want to see me no longer producing images of any kind.

The shoot days are the 24th-28th of April.

The Schedule-

April 23rd- Rococo picnic at the Salton Sea starring the Flying Morgans


April 24th- Pin-Up


April 25th- Circus, Magic, and Bellydancing

April 26th- Vintage nudes

April 27th- ANGEL DONOR DAY- DONATE $300 and get a 2 hour private shoot at the Salton Sea, up to 3 people in a shoot.

My estimated cost is $200 per day, including food, shelter, and equipment rental. Does not include lost wages. 

The location- the Salton sea is remote. The beach is made of fishbones. It is the most beautiful place you will ever see.

story:
In 2015, we have reinvented the classic Holga camera. Updated for the digital age yet retaining the simplicity and fun of the Holga camera, Holga Digital has became a hit and was loved by photographers from first-timers to professionals. Without requiring precise settings, Holga adds inspiration and creativity with its subtle randomness on every shot.

Before back when digital photography has not become the common pastime as it is now, the solid photographs are considered to be ceremonious and are often used on commemorative occasions. With the increasing ease of taking photos, done simply with a smartphone, we feel like the essence of this once memorable experience has been gradually slipping away. Perhaps to really capture that beautiful moment, a digital photograph is simply not enough.

 

 

Holga has been producing cameras for 30-odd years. Mr. T.M. Lee started Holga as a company manufacturing quality external flash. As external flash was made increasingly obsolete by cameras with integrated flash, Holga came up with the idea to build an affordable camera for the emerging Chinese Mainland market, where 120mm film was then still the norm. In 1982, the legendary Holga 120 was born. To Mr Lee’s amazement, the camera was met with more interest worldwide, as people appreciated its simple yet reliable construction and ease of use.

Yet, Holga did not stop at the 120. Starting from the basic 120, Holga worked around and made multiple upgrades to the 120, remarkably the popular 120N with a hotshoe and the 120CFN with a built-in flash and color filters.

Moving towards the mid-80s, Lee made another camera for 135 films and logically named it Holga 135. The 135 platform proved to be extremely reliable and versatile. It has been modified into 135 panoramic, 135 TLR and even the famous 135TIM, of which the buttons are arranged in a smiley face and takes half-frame photos on a single film.

Additionally, Holga has made dozens of other cameras ranging from the Micro 110 to the 120-3D Stereo Camera, all preserving the unique distortion, lens flares and vignettes of the original Holga.

In the past few decades, Holga camera was being used for its surrealistic, impressionistic scenes for landscape, still life, portrait, and more notably street photography. A Holga photograph, which was taken by photojournalist David Burnett of former vice-president Al Gore, during a 2000 campaign appearance earned the top prize in a 2001 White House News Photographers' Association Eyes of History award ceremony. Famous photojournalist Teru Kuwayama was rarely seen without his Holga, as it is the most versatile and reliable camera in the wilds of Iraq and Afghanistan.

Instant camera has been bulky, uncontrollable and uninspiring. This is changed with Holga Printer.

Holga is always open to new ideas. In the 2010s, the function of camera is gradually overtaken by smartphones. While adding some smart functions into the camera to compete with the phone seems to be the trend, we would rather strive to incorporate the phone itself.

With the same philosophy, we proudly present you the Holga Printer. We designed the printer as the Holga 120 of 2018. All the while utilizing the most common electronic device today – smartphone. Together with our exclusive app, users can now produce Holga-styled photos and have them developed on the Holga printer through the use of Fuji Instax mini film. The whole printing process is completely manual so batteries are not required at all.

Another Holga product coming out with the printer will be its mobile counterpart, the HolgaCam app. Coupled with the Holga Printer, you will be able to start working on that scrapbook of precious memories.

 See the Holga Printer in action!

Instant photography has made a strong comeback recently. In an age where a flawless photo can be taken on many devices with a single click, a physical photograph is more cherished than ever. While millions of digital photos are stored and easily forgotten, a few chosen printed photographs are framed and displayed.

The classic instant camera makers have released new models, but they remain largely the same as their ancestors. As the printer is linked directly to the camera, every shot is printed out directly in the same fixed style and effect.

This is changed with Holga printer. With the app, you'll be able to use the camera of your phone to capture memories and apply classic and beloved Holga filters and effects before printing it out. Forgot to take the printer with you? No worries, just capture those moments now and print them out later. As you crank the dial, watch as your personally bring that treasured memory to life through the Holga printer.

At first glance, our Printer looks like a Holga 120 without the lens. It also comes in the iconic bright, vibrant colors featured on many Holga cameras, along with our logo presented proudly on the cover. The design is equally nostalgic. Parts are made of molded polymer with cleverly designed joints, so little need for bolts and fasteners. Just like other Holga products, the appearance of the Holga printer is as iconic. It adds character to any space no matter it is sitting on your shelf or placed on the table of your favorite cafe.

While little has changed regarding instant cameras since the 80s, the Holga Printer takes the full advantage of modern technology and will print photos in the effect of your choice.

A tailored mobile app, available to both iOS and Android, will be released along with the printer. With our app, you will be able to print an unprocessed photo with the recommended settings or blend in classic Holga filter effects to create different vibes for your chosen shots. Extensive research has been done to recreate the Holga experience digitally. Through the Holga filter design, the Holga printer app will be able to convert your phone-snaps into authentic and realistic Holga shots. With our app, you will also be able to add text and icons to your photos, opening up unlimited design possibilities.

We have carefully selected Fuji Instax mini film for its affordability and world-wide availability. Each cartridge contains 10 shots and can swap in seconds. The instant film prints crisp photo and our printer takes full advantage of it. The film fully develops within minutes after being released from printer.

There is more to the Holga printer. We have incorporated many new technologies to make the Holga Printer the first choice for creating unique, artistic and stylish instant photos. All aimed to bring you the perfect option for your throwback vibes and nostalgic vintage needs.

Modern Construction: Modern anti-slip materials and magnets has been incorporated into the printer's design for a better user experience. As a result, the Holga Printer is less heavy as well as easier to operate than the average photo-printer. With its quick and easy assemble nature, manifesting those valuable moments into physical photographs comes both smoothly and nicely. Operation is really simple – many people are able to unfold the camera and replace film cartridge on their first try - without any instruction! Just like our cameras.

Folding Sun Blind: For the optimized photo quality, a dark space and a certain distance is required between your phone and the printer shutter. Taking inspiration from early folding cameras, we have revived the foldable design to facilitate the required environment.. The printer itself may be relatively large in size, however once it is folded, it is no bigger than the Holga 120.With its simple folding design, the Holga Printer can be easily carried around. Whether it be a picnic out with friends, a family road trip, or a self-exploration journey, you will be able to take the Holga Printer and create those precious memories.

No Battery Needed: In our increasingly gadget-filled lives, the Holga printer is purposely designed to be a purely manual device. That’s one less charging cable in life, but one more soothing connection to your photography experience.

Exclusive Precision Frame: To help users better align their photos, the Holga Printer has a detachable precision frame that is made from modern magnets and a special adhesive rubber. This allows better precision when positioning the phone above the printer shutter. The adhesive rubber will stick to the phone surface while leaving it scratch-free, while the magnet will allow the frame to snap neatly back into the required position for printing.

No WiFi/Bluetooth Required: Inspirations and emotions come at spontaneous moments. To not hinder this wonder process, the Holga Printer allows user to print photos without the use of any wireless connections. Photo-printing can be done simply by placing the phone on top of the printer. No more connection issues or buffering time, just instant and beautiful moments.

The Classic Holga Mechanism: With its classic shutter and spherical lens, the Holga Printer retains the magic of the Holga cameras. However, with the Holga Printer, we are bringing back the beloved feature of the Holga 120: the power to create double-exposure photos. With the printer, you will be able to interpose photos on top of another easily on a single film. Yet, why stop at two? The Holga Printer allows multiple photos to be overlayed together at once, hence creating a unique piece that no other instant printer can do.

Example photos printed with our first prototype.

Example photos printed with our first prototype.

 

Back in 2015, when we were working on the Holga Digital project, we digitalised the iconic Holga camera and users were able to enjoy the fun of taking pictures again. Yet, there was more to the iconic Holga 120N, which was Holga a classic camera back in the 2000s, that couldn’t be achieved with Holga Digital back then: The Holga 120 Instant back, which was an added extension to the Holga 120N to allow it to print photos and hence, transforming the Holga 120N into the Holga Instant Camera Since the success of the Holga Digital project, we have been working to revive that feature and we are happy to announce that we did it. 

By utilizing the same optical technology on the Holga Printer, users are now able to print out Holga-styled photos just like many did with the Holga Instant Camera before. We strive to make the experience more accessible, smoother and most of all, more authentic and true to the classic Holga experience that many has grown to love and enjoy. The Holga 120N may be gradually fading out of the spotlight, but through the Holga Printer, its essence lives on.

For our avid supporters, we’ve put together this nice package of goods that will jumpstart your Holga Printer user experience:

(1) Holga Exclusive Bag (2) Holga Printer (3) Fujifilm Instant Film x 20 sheets

T.M. Lee - created the Holga. His vision was to inspire millions of Chinese to create lasting memories with this simple and affordable camera, at a time when photography was an expensive luxury in China that few could indulge in. Today, more than two decades later, the Holga has inspired millions throughout the world with the unique imagery it creates in the hands of the inspired artist. The Holga has become a classic.

Share Holga Printer:

As the printer is linked directly to the camera, every shot is printed out directly in the same fixed style and effect.This is changed with Holga printer. With the app, you'll be able to use the camera of your phone to capture memories and apply classic and beloved Holga filters and effects before printing it out. Forgot to take the printer with you? No worries, just capture those moments now and print them out later. As you crank the dial, watch as your personally bring that treasured memory to life through the Holga printer.At first glance, our Printer looks like a Holga 120 without the lens. It also comes in the iconic bright, vibrant colors featured on many Holga cameras, along with our logo presented proudly on the cover. The design is equally nostalgic. Parts are made of molded polymer with cleverly designed joints, so little need for bolts and fasteners. Just like other Holga products, the appearance of the Holga printer is as iconic. It adds character to any space no matter it is sitting on your shelf or placed on the table of your favorite cafe.While little has changed regarding instant cameras since the 80s, the Holga Printer takes the full advantage of modern technology and will print photos in the effect of your choice.A tailored mobile app, available to both iOS and Android, will be released along with the printer. With our app, you will be able to print an unprocessed photo with the recommended settings or blend in classic Holga filter effects to create different vibes for your chosen shots. Extensive research has been done to recreate the Holga experience digitally. Through the Holga filter design, the Holga printer app will be able to convert your phone-snaps into authentic and realistic Holga shots. With our app, you will also be able to add text and icons to your photos, opening up unlimited design possibilities.We have carefully selected Fuji Instax mini film for its affordability and world-wide availability. Each cartridge contains 10 shots and can swap in seconds. The instant film prints crisp photo and our printer takes full advantage of it. The film fully develops within minutes after being released from printer.There is more to the Holga printer. We have incorporated many new technologies to make the Holga Printer the first choice for creating unique, artistic and stylish instant photos. All aimed to bring you the perfect option for your throwback vibes and nostalgic vintage needs.Modern Construction: Modern anti-slip materials and magnets has been incorporated into the printer's design for a better user experience. As a result, the Holga Printer is less heavy as well as easier to operate than the average photo-printer. With its quick and easy assemble nature, manifesting those valuable moments into physical photographs comes both smoothly and nicely. Operation is really simple – many people are able to unfold the camera and replace film cartridge on their first try - without any instruction! Just like our cameras.Folding Sun Blind: For the optimized photo quality, a dark space and a certain distance is required between your phone and the printer shutter. Taking inspiration from early folding cameras, we have revived the foldable design to facilitate the required environment.. The printer itself may be relatively large in size, however once it is folded, it is no bigger than the Holga 120.With its simple folding design, the Holga Printer can be easily carried around. Whether it be a picnic out with friends, a family road trip, or a self-exploration journey, you will be able to take the Holga Printer and create those precious memories.No Battery Needed: In our increasingly gadget-filled lives, the Holga printer is purposely designed to be a purely manual device. That’s one less charging cable in life, but one more soothing connection to your photography experience.Exclusive Precision Frame: To help users better align their photos, the Holga Printer has a detachable precision frame that is made from modern magnets and a special adhesive rubber. This allows better precision when positioning the phone above the printer shutter. The adhesive rubber will stick to the phone surface while leaving it scratch-free, while the magnet will allow the frame to snap neatly back into the required position for printing.No WiFi/Bluetooth Required: Inspirations and emotions come at spontaneous moments. To not hinder this wonder process, the Holga Printer allows user to print photos without the use of any wireless connections. Photo-printing can be done simply by placing the phone on top of the printer. No more connection issues or buffering time, just instant and beautiful moments.The Classic Holga Mechanism: With its classic shutter and spherical lens, the Holga Printer retains the magic of the Holga cameras. However, with the Holga Printer, we are bringing back the beloved feature of the Holga 120: the power to create double-exposure photos. With the printer, you will be able to interpose photos on top of another easily on a single film. Yet, why stop at two? The Holga Printer allows multiple photos to be overlayed together at once, hence creating a unique piece that no other instant printer can do.Example photos printed with our first prototype.Example photos printed with our first prototype. Back in 2015, when we were working on the Holga Digital project, we digitalised the iconic Holga camera and users were able to enjoy the fun of taking pictures again. Yet, there was more to the iconic Holga 120N, which was Holga a classic camera back in the 2000s, that couldn’t be achieved with Holga Digital back then: The Holga 120 Instant back, which was an added extension to the Holga 120N to allow it to print photos and hence, transforming the Holga 120N into the Holga Instant Camera Since the success of the Holga Digital project, we have been working to revive that feature and we are happy to announce that we did it. By utilizing the same optical technology on the Holga Printer, users are now able to print out Holga-styled photos just like many did with the Holga Instant Camera before. We strive to make the experience more accessible, smoother and most of all, more authentic and true to the classic Holga experience that many has grown to love and enjoy. The Holga 120N may be gradually fading out of the spotlight, but through the Holga Printer, its essence lives on.For our avid supporters, we’ve put together this nice package of goods that will jumpstart your Holga Printer user experience:(1) Holga Exclusive Bag (2) Holga Printer (3) Fujifilm Instant Film x 20 sheetsT.M. Lee - created the Holga. His vision was to inspire millions of Chinese to create lasting memories with this simple and affordable camera, at a time when photography was an expensive luxury in China that few could indulge in. Today, more than two decades later, the Holga has inspired millions throughout the world with the unique imagery it creates in the hands of the inspired artist. The Holga has become a classic.Share Holga Printer:

story:
Chi siamo

Io (Nelb) ed Emanuele siamo fotografi, prevalentemente ritrattisti. Se vi state interessando alla campagna molto probabilmente siete tra i follower che supportano la nostra fotografia, sia su Instagram che su Youtube nel mio caso.


Se volete vedere i nostri portfolio:

  • Nelb Rodrigues: https://nelbrodrigues.com/
  • Emanuele di Mare: https://emanueledimare.com/ 

 

L'idea

Vogliamo produrre un contenuto  che possa sottolineare gli svariati aspetti inerenti ai nostri shooting che per molto tempo avete richiesto. Sfrutteremo  quindi il nostro prossimo set insieme per veicolare questo contenuto. Il genere ovviamente sarà ritratto con il nostro tocco personale.

Sarà un set realizzato in una location professionale con  modelle professioniste e un videomaker a supporto.

Questo contenuto sarà un video pubblicato sul mio canale Youtube in cui spiegheremo nel migliore dei modi (secondo le nostre capacità) quella che è la progettazione, la fase di scatto e l'editing dei nostri scatti fino ad arrivare al prodotto finale.

Abbiamo deciso di fare questo video insieme perché molto spesso ci siamo trovati a realizzare set fotografici insieme e condividiamo la maggior parte del processo creativo inerenti ad essi.

 

Motivazione della Campagna

La campagna ha lo scopo di supportare economicamente tutte le spese citate sopra. 
N.B: Leggere il paragrafo "Alcuni chiarimenti"

 

Alcuni Chiarimenti

  1. Il video verrà prodotto anche in parziale o totale assenza di supporto della community a nostre spese.
  2. I soldi servono a darci più agio nella creazione. Maggiore è il supporto, maggiore potrà essere la qualità del video finale.
  3. La campagna non è a scopo di lucro ovvero non è nostro obbiettivo guadagnare da questo contenuto.
  4. Il ricavato superfluo verrà utilizzato per supportare "Creators Magazine" nella sua seconda edizione.

story:
Summary:

Green Project aims to give a voice to underprivileged teens through photography as they explore self-identity in relation to their environment; promoting positive self-esteem.

In 2013 we hope to buy, distribute and process 300 cameras for teens directly affected by domestic abuse, poverty and disability. We plan to then showcase these images online and in museum & gallery settings in order to raise awareness, highlight diversity, and  illustrate through the creative process that their present circumstance does not define them nor diminish their worth. We strongly believe, that the while the cameras are disposable, the voices behind them are not.

Currently slated to work with teens affected by domestic violence in Larimer County, Colorado and in collaboration with deaf students in Mumbai, India; we seek to soon expand our efforts to some of the poorest counties in the United States, many on or near Native American reservations where teen suicide rates have reached epidemic proportions.

Green Project currently operates solely as an artistic endeavor (awaiting 501(c)3 recognition) teamed by dedicated volunteers with extensive backgrounds in holistic health, psychology and the visual arts. We are:

  • Kat Webb   Founder & Curator. Certified Holistic Health Practitioner. Art Historian. @art_smarts
  • Lindsay Strand   Queen of Operations. Psychology Consultant. Health Information Specialist. @stretch_forth
  • Amy Driver   Creative Consultant. Graphic Designer. Artist, Photographer & Art Historian. @creativ_drive

Goal:

Our Mission for 2013 is to obtain and distribute 300 disposable cameras to underprivileged children locally in Colorado, nationally and globally:

  • 100 to be given to local teens, displaced by domestic violence and/or at-risk youth participating in similar community outreach programs
  • 100 to be distributed to teens growing up in the poorest counties in the United States ( as defined by the last US Census)
  • 100 to be given to Deaf Photography Students in Mumbai, India under the direction of noted photographer Rajen Nair @rajennair

Our ultimate goal is to then display the images collected in museum and/or gallery settings, highlighting diversity and commonalities among participants. 

All participants will receive prints of their work, and be required to choose a pseudonym to use in place of their name to best protect their identities and encourage them to give accurate and honest depictions of their social and physical environments without individual fear of ridicule or punishment.

Challenges:

Currently our project's greatest obstacle is funding & with your support that can change! Our funding request covers the cost of processing 300 cameras at an estimated cost of $100 dollars apiece in order to ensure deliver, return of prints, processing and getting the images ‘gallery ready’. Any additional funding raised for our project, will be used to offset operational costs which may arise from the our need to travel as a team, reimburse our volunteers for costs incurred, obtain additional operating equipment, and acquire office space (if necessary) to maintain the day-to-day operations of the project in order to best ensure its success.

In terms of local community involvement, we are soon slated to begin our work with a domestic violence shelter which serves as a safe haven for teens affected by abuse. We also have a longstanding relationship with an after-school outreach program targeting at-risk youth through a local university. Therefore, the ability to positively impact our own community is assured. We have the kids, we just need the cameras and the means.

Through our academic educations & personal histories we have well established connections to various Native American communities and reservations throughout the United States, where teen suicide rates have reached alarming rates and far exceed the national average. We hope to target at least three counties affected by this crisis. A large portion of our funding will go toward ensuring we can meet with these participants, at least quarterly, in order to teach and/or assure they are familiar with basic principles of photography before distributing disposable cameras. We believe by establishing lasting relationships with participants over the coming year and being a consistent presence, it best guarantees the success of our project. What is best for the kids, is also best for us.

Noted photographer, Rajen Nair, will be assisting us in India by distributing cameras to Deaf Photography Students in Mumbai. We may experience some delays in shipment/ delivery with this group as no specific date ranges have been set. We will keep our sponsors updated routinely.

Our small but mighty team exists solely of three part-time volunteers. Therefore, our travel schedule will have to coordinate with personal, educational and professional commits already in place. We realize however that traveling is an essential component to the success to of our project and it is our aim to have all collected images processed no later than December 31, 2013.

The main focus of our current project is to obtain, distribute and acquire a diverse collection of images from the 300 cameras/ participants locally, nationally and globally. While our ultimate goal is showcase a large selection of these images in museum and galleries settings, time and funding may limit our ability to reach a wide audience range by the end of the year. Therefore we'll also be featuring a vast majority of these images online through various social media sites and webpages associated with our project.

How You Can Help Support Our Project:

Find us on Facebook: facebook.com/Green.Teens.Project

Follow us on Twitter: @gree_project

Fiddle with our pins on Pinterest: pinterest.com/greenproject/ 

Fawn over us on Instagram: GREE_PROJECT

Figure out more about us on Tumblr: gree-project.tumblr.com

Fool with us on Foursquare: foursquare.com/gree_project

...and of course share our project with your friends!

story:
About the Campaign

The Eastern Sierra Center for Photography (ESC4P) is the brainchild of founder Laura Campbell, an accomplished and published large format photographer.

 

The Center was conceived to promote the use of large format photography across economic, gender, and age boundaries.

 

This campaign is designed to launch our floating-platform Artist-in-Residence program. ESC4P seeks to fund 4 week-long programs in one of two locations, the chosen artists selecting the spot. Choices will be Lone Pine, CA, site of the Alabama Hills and close to Mt Whitney, Death Valley, the Eastern Sierra, and the Owens Valley, or Jerome AZ, an historic mining town with early western architecture in driving distance to Sedona, and the Grand Canyon.

The Center has partnered with View Camera Magazine, and artists will have their work published in the only periodical devoted exclusively to large format photography.

We will also be launching a Kids-In-the-Arts program in summer 2014, in Lone Pine, CA. We will begin with 2-day pilot programs to develop the appropriate curriculum, but always featuring large format work. Scholarships will be funded by ESC4P and a nominal charge to non-scholarship participants. We want to make our craft available to all who show interest.

Our long term goal is to have a facility in Lone Pine CA, where we can set up a darkroom, gallery, and class space.
We will make the space available to visiting photographers as well as for seminars, workshops, and shows not limited to photography in the hope of promoting art in general.

What We Need and What You Get

What we need is funding for stipends and scholarships for Artist-in-Residence (AIR) photographers, material expenses, such as insurance, utilities, and renting a space for a darkroom for the AIR participant, and a small salary for the accompanying member of ESC4P. 

For every residency that provides a stipend, there will be another that provides a stipend and scholarship that covers accommodation; the artist just needs to get to the site.

What you get for helping out, besides a happy glow, is a variety of goodies depending on your level of contribution. Hand silk-screened t-shirts; prints from Jim Fitzgerald, Laura Campbell, and Austin Granger; View Camera Magazine subscriptions; private workshops with Jim Fitzgerald or Laura Campbell; a custom made hand-knitted hat to keep you warm on winter shoots; a lush book of photographs by Austin Granger; a vacation rental, and more.

The Impact

Everyone wants to know that their treasured pastime, valued hobby, or livelihood will persist into the future. Large format photography is no different, especially in this day and age when many wonder why we do it anyway.

Funding an artist-in-residence program, and later education and outreach efforts, we spread the word about our craft.

Teaching teens about how to use a large camera gives an extraordinary sense of accomplishment, and we aim to make it as easy and immediate as possible. We'll use pinholes and instant film as well as printing out paper to mimic what we already see in digital media. Using a large camera teaches patience and perseverance, as well as develops the artistic eye.

 

Doing things 'old school' is perennially popular with the young and is where we plant the seeds for the longevity of our passion.
 
You can learn more about ESC4P's Artist-in-Residence (AIR) Program by scrolling down this campaign page. 

 

Ways You Can Help

Lots of folks have shown their support for our fledgling organization by signing up for our mailing list on esc4p.org and telling their friends about us. We hope you will help us out by contributing to our campaign, and also spreading the word.

 

Eastern Sierra Center for Photography, Inc
Board Directors
  • President: Laura Campbell
  • Secretary: Bill Waldron
  • Treasurer: Amanda Tomlin

 

Please allow 3 weeks to receive your perks. This gives our fiscal sponsor time to process your contribution, and participating artists to prepare your gifts. 

 

ESC4P T-shirt

Be sure to sport your ESC4P t-shirt silkscreened by plein air painter Mark Hemleben on your next shoot to be the envy of all your pals.  Upon receiving your contribution, you will receive a thank you letter from ESC4P with a request for your t-shirt size.  

 

View Camera Magazine

 

View Camera
Photo courtesy View Camera
 

Laura Campbell

Stripes, Death Valley, CA
Photograph by Laura Campbell
Founder, ESC4P
8x10 Negative, Archival Pigment Ink Print

Near Movie Road, Lone Pine, CA
Photograph by Laura Campbell
Founder, ESC4P
