Austin Granger

Early Morning Sculptured Beach
Photograph by Austin Granger
Silver Gelatin Print
8x10 contact print, matted to 14x17
 
 
Tomales Bay
Photograph by Austin Granger
Silver Gelatin Print
11x14 from a 4x5 negative, matted to 16x20
 
 
The Point Reyes Unusually High Tide Tomales Bay
Photograph by Austin Granger
Silver Gelatin Print
11x14 from a 4x5 negative, matted to 16x20
 
 
Clearing Storm Drakes Bay
Photograph by Austin Granger
Silver Gelatin Print
11x14 from a 6x9 negative, matted to 16x20
 
 
Large Wave Little Bird McClures Beach
Photograph by Austin Granger
Silver Gelatin Print
11x14 from a 4x5 negative, matted to 16x20
 

Jim Fitzgerald

 
Eye of the Oak
Photograph by Jim Fitzgerald
8x10 Carbon Transfer Contact Print

Matted on 4-ply Alpha Rag with an 8-Ply Alpha rag museum window, corner mounted and signed by Jim Fitzgerald on the print under the window mount. All information is on the back of the print, and a certificate of authenticity is included with each print. A limited edition of 5 prints. Printed on 1964 Ilford Bromide paper as the final substrate.
 

Jim Fitzgerald's Two-Day Carbon Workshop

In Jim's Carbon Workshop, the student will learn to mix and pour the pigmented gelatin coating and the reasons behind making one's own tissue, sensitizing, printing with the NuArc 26 1KS UV exposure unit, transferring, developing and finishing a print. A discussion regarding the proper negative for carbon printing will be addressed as well.
 
The student will use the instructor's negatives to print from on day one, and on day two the student will use their own negatives to print from. All materials will be provided and a light lunch will be served each day.
Please note that the workshop gift requires travel to Ventura, CA. The workshop participant is responsible for travel, food, and lodging expenses.
 

Amanda Tomlin's Bonkhead Hats

 
Bonkhead Hats
Limited Edition Hats by Amanda Tomlin
Treasurer, ESC4P
Hand Knitted for your noggin
 

Austin Granger's book, "Point Reyes"

Study a map of Point Reyes and the names of its features as christened by its past explorers seem as if from fiction, from myth, as if from some ancient allegory: Point Resistance, Mount Vision, Secret Beach... There is a tangible air of mystery that permeates the peninsula as surely as its summer fogs. And nowhere on earth have I so strongly sensed the immanence of the Spirit.

Featuring eighty-three of my favorite photographs of the peninsula, "Point Reyes" is a testimonial borne of my adventures in that most extraordinary place.

"Beautiful" –Diana Landau, Senior Editor, Sierra Club Press

"Wonderful" –Michael A. Smith, Lodima Press

"Captivating" –Claire Chandler, Merrell Publishers

Author Bio

Born in San Francisco in 1970, Austin Granger has worked as a baker, house painter, naval radar operator and camera salesman. He first began to photograph while studying philosophy in college as a way to get out of his head. Preferring to use a traditional view camera, Granger has come to see his photography as a spiritual practice–a way in which to shape his life, and enrich his relationship with the world. He likes motorcycles a lot too.

Laura Campbell's "Improved Negatives" Workshop

Fine Tune Your Vision With Improved Negatives
Please note that the workshop gift requires travel to Jerome, AZ. The workshop participant is responsible for travel, food, and lodging expenses. At the $2000 gift level, lodging is provided at the Jerome Historical Society Vacation Rental.  
Laura Campbell
Founder, ESC4P
Workshop Flyer
 

Jerome Historical Society Vacation Rental

Vacation Rental, Boyd Hotel, Jerome, AZ
Photo courtesy Jerome Historical Society

The Boyd Hotel was built in 1898 after Kitty Christians' original structure burned down. Kitty then married John D. Boyd in 1889. She renamed the new brick three story structure the Boyd Hotel. The upper two floors were a residence and transient Hotel. The lower housed multiple businesses over the years including a Meat market, the Club Bar, Billie's Exchange (saloon) a drug store and even a mortuary.

The building was purchased by the Jerome Historical Society in 1956. In 1978 the first floor was repaired to use as retail spaces. In 2003 the Society received matching funds from Arizona State Parks Historic Preservation Heritage Fund to restore the upper two floors. The upper two floors now have three apartments and one vacation rental managed by the Society.
 
 
 

ESC4P AIR Program

ESC4P and View Camera

ESC4P has partnered with View Camera Magazine. Artists participating in our Artist-in-Residence program will have their work published in the only periodical devoted exclusively to large format photography. Thank you Steve Simmons for your generosity and support.

What connects us all is our passion for large format photography. Let’s unite as a community and support one another. Together we can promote the continued use of the large format camera.
About the ESC4P AIR Program

Our artist-in-residency is open to anyone shooting large format, film or digital. Each artist will submit an application, a portfolio, and a letter explaining their goals for a residency. Subject matter while participating is wholly artist-driven though there are some expectations on behalf of ESC4P.

The resident is expected to donate 2 prints to the organization and an additional print to be gifted to either the Southern Inyo Hospital (if the residency is in Lone Pine), or the Jerome Historical Society for Jerome residencies.

The artist is also expected to plan one event to share their work with the public within the community they select, either an informal lecture or a demonstration. He or she will be aided in this endeavor by ESC4P staff who will provide the venue and supporting logistics. The event will be video taped to share online for public education.

Upon completion of the residency, the artist’s work will be featured in View Camera Magazine. At least two images must be from the residency, preferably more. The work will also be showcased on our website. When enough residencies have been completed, the work will become part of a traveling exhibit.

To Sum Up

Our artist-in-residency is open to anyone shooting large format, film or digital.

The artist must:

  • Submit an application
  • Submit a portfolio
  • Submit a letter outlining his or her goals for the residency

The artist will receive:

  • A stipend of $1400 for covering expenses or, for artists with financial need, a scholarship of the stipend of $1400 + the cost of accommodation
  • Publication in View Camera Magazine (note that at least 2 images must be from the residency)
  • Work showcased on the ESC4P website
  • Participation in a traveling exhibit when enough residencies have been completed

The resident artist is expected to provide ESC4P the following:

  • Hold one public event, either a lecture or demonstration
  • This will be videotaped and shared online for public education
  • ESC4P staff will provide the support for venue, advertising, etc
  • Donate 2 prints from the residency
  • Donate 1 print to be gifted to a charitable organization in the residency area

For every dollar donated to our current fundraising campaign, 80 cents goes directly to funding. The 20% overhead covers the cost of perks, postage, and the administrative fee we pay to Fractured Atlas, our fiscal sponsor. Members of the Board of Directors receive only the cost of materials for any item they donate.
story_txt:
About the Campaign

The Eastern Sierra Center for Photography (ESC4P) is the brainchild of founder Laura Campbell, an accomplished and published large format photographer.
 

The Center was conceived to promote the use of large format photography across economic, gender, and age boundaries.
 
This campaign is designed to launch our floating-platform Artist-in-Residence program. ESC4P seeks to fund 4 week-long programs in one of two locations, the chosen artists selecting the spot. Choices will be Lone Pine, CA, site of the Alabama Hills and close to Mt Whitney, Death Valley, the Eastern Sierra, and the Owens Valley, or Jerome AZ, an historic mining town with early western architecture in driving distance to Sedona, and the Grand Canyon.
The Center has partnered with View Camera Magazine, and artists will have their work published in the only periodical devoted exclusively to large format photography.
We will also be launching a Kids-In-the-Arts program in summer 2014, in Lone Pine, CA. We will begin with 2-day pilot programs to develop the appropriate curriculum, but always featuring large format work. Scholarships will be funded by ESC4P and a nominal charge to non-scholarship participants. We want to make our craft available to all who show interest.
Our long term goal is to have a facility in Lone Pine CA, where we can set up a darkroom, gallery, and class space.

We will make the space available to visiting photographers as well as for seminars, workshops, and shows not limited to photography in the hope of promoting art in general.

What We Need and What You Get
What we need is funding for stipends and scholarships for Artist-in-Residence (AIR) photographers, material expenses, such as insurance, utilities, and renting a space for a darkroom for the AIR participant, and a small salary for the accompanying member of ESC4P. 
For every residency that provides a stipend, there will be another that provides a stipend and scholarship that covers accommodation; the artist just needs to get to the site.
What you get for helping out, besides a happy glow, is a variety of goodies depending on your level of contribution. Hand silk-screened t-shirts; prints from Jim Fitzgerald, Laura Campbell, and Austin Granger; View Camera Magazine subscriptions; private workshops with Jim Fitzgerald or Laura Campbell; a custom made hand-knitted hat to keep you warm on winter shoots; a lush book of photographs by Austin Granger; a vacation rental, and more.


The Impact
Everyone wants to know that their treasured pastime, valued hobby, or livelihood will persist into the future. Large format photography is no different, especially in this day and age when many wonder why we do it anyway.
Funding an artist-in-residence program, and later education and outreach efforts, we spread the word about our craft.
Teaching teens about how to use a large camera gives an extraordinary sense of accomplishment, and we aim to make it as easy and immediate as possible. We'll use pinholes and instant film as well as printing out paper to mimic what we already see in digital media. Using a large camera teaches patience and perseverance, as well as develops the artistic eye.
 

Doing things 'old school' is perennially popular with the young and is where we plant the seeds for the longevity of our passion.


 

You can learn more about ESC4P's Artist-in-Residence (AIR) Program by scrolling down this campaign page. 
 
Ways You Can Help


Lots of folks have shown their support for our fledgling organization by signing up for our mailing list on esc4p.org and telling their friends about us. We hope you will help us out by contributing to our campaign, and also spreading the word.
 
Eastern Sierra Center for Photography, Inc

Board Directors


President: Laura Campbell
Secretary: Bill Waldron
Treasurer: Amanda Tomlin



 
Please allow 3 weeks to receive your perks. This gives our fiscal sponsor time to process your contribution, and participating artists to prepare your gifts. 
 
ESC4P T-shirt
Be sure to sport your ESC4P t-shirt silkscreened by plein air painter Mark Hemleben on your next shoot to be the envy of all your pals.  Upon receiving your contribution, you will receive a thank you letter from ESC4P with a request for your t-shirt size.  
 
View Camera Magazine


 

View CameraPhoto courtesy View Camera
 
Laura Campbell


Stripes, Death Valley, CAPhotograph by Laura CampbellFounder, ESC4P8x10 Negative, Archival Pigment Ink Print


Near Movie Road, Lone Pine, CAPhotograph by Laura CampbellFounder, ESC4P8x10 Negative, Archival Pigment Ink Print
 
Austin Granger

Early Morning Sculptured Beach
Photograph by Austin Granger
Silver Gelatin Print
8x10 contact print, matted to 14x17
 

 
Tomales Bay
Photograph by Austin Granger
Silver Gelatin Print
11x14 from a 4x5 negative, matted to 16x20
 

 
The Point Reyes Unusually High Tide Tomales Bay
Photograph by Austin Granger
Silver Gelatin Print
11x14 from a 4x5 negative, matted to 16x20
 

 
Clearing Storm Drakes Bay
Photograph by Austin Granger
Silver Gelatin Print
11x14 from a 6x9 negative, matted to 16x20
 

 
Large Wave Little Bird McClures Beach
Photograph by Austin Granger
Silver Gelatin Print
11x14 from a 4x5 negative, matted to 16x20
 
Jim Fitzgerald
 


Eye of the OakPhotograph by Jim Fitzgerald8x10 Carbon Transfer Contact PrintMatted on 4-ply Alpha Rag with an 8-Ply Alpha rag museum window, corner mounted and signed by Jim Fitzgerald on the print under the window mount. All information is on the back of the print, and a certificate of authenticity is included with each print. A limited edition of 5 prints. Printed on 1964 Ilford Bromide paper as the final substrate.
 
Jim Fitzgerald's Two-Day Carbon Workshop
In Jim's Carbon Workshop, the student will learn to mix and pour the pigmented gelatin coating and the reasons behind making one's own tissue, sensitizing, printing with the NuArc 26 1KS UV exposure unit, transferring, developing and finishing a print. A discussion regarding the proper negative for carbon printing will be addressed as well.

 
The student will use the instructor's negatives to print from on day one, and on day two the student will use their own negatives to print from. All materials will be provided and a light lunch will be served each day.Please note that the workshop gift requires travel to Ventura, CA. The workshop participant is responsible for travel, food, and lodging expenses.

 
Amanda Tomlin's Bonkhead Hats

 

Bonkhead HatsLimited Edition Hats by Amanda TomlinTreasurer, ESC4PHand Knitted for your noggin
 
Austin Granger's book, "Point Reyes"


Study a map of Point Reyes and the names of its features as christened by its past explorers seem as if from fiction, from myth, as if from some ancient allegory: Point Resistance, Mount Vision, Secret Beach... There is a tangible air of mystery that permeates the peninsula as surely as its summer fogs. And nowhere on earth have I so strongly sensed the immanence of the Spirit.
Featuring eighty-three of my favorite photographs of the peninsula, "Point Reyes" is a testimonial borne of my adventures in that most extraordinary place.
"Beautiful" –Diana Landau, Senior Editor, Sierra Club Press
"Wonderful" –Michael A. Smith, Lodima Press
"Captivating" –Claire Chandler, Merrell Publishers
Author Bio
Born in San Francisco in 1970, Austin Granger has worked as a baker, house painter, naval radar operator and camera salesman. He first began to photograph while studying philosophy in college as a way to get out of his head. Preferring to use a traditional view camera, Granger has come to see his photography as a spiritual practice–a way in which to shape his life, and enrich his relationship with the world. He likes motorcycles a lot too.
Laura Campbell's "Improved Negatives" Workshop


Fine Tune Your Vision With Improved NegativesPlease note that the workshop gift requires travel to Jerome, AZ. The workshop participant is responsible for travel, food, and lodging expenses. At the $2000 gift level, lodging is provided at the Jerome Historical Society Vacation Rental.  Laura CampbellFounder, ESC4PWorkshop Flyer
 
Jerome Historical Society Vacation Rental


Vacation Rental, Boyd Hotel, Jerome, AZPhoto courtesy Jerome Historical SocietyThe Boyd Hotel was built in 1898 after Kitty Christians' original structure burned down. Kitty then married John D. Boyd in 1889. She renamed the new brick three story structure the Boyd Hotel. The upper two floors were a residence and transient Hotel. The lower housed multiple businesses over the years including a Meat market, the Club Bar, Billie's Exchange (saloon) a drug store and even a mortuary. The building was purchased by the Jerome Historical Society in 1956. In 1978 the first floor was repaired to use as retail spaces. In 2003 the Society received matching funds from Arizona State Parks Historic Preservation Heritage Fund to restore the upper two floors. The upper two floors now have three apartments and one vacation rental managed by the Society.
 
 
 

ESC4P AIR Program
ESC4P and View Camera
ESC4P has partnered with View Camera Magazine. Artists participating in our Artist-in-Residence program will have their work published in the only periodical devoted exclusively to large format photography. Thank you Steve Simmons for your generosity and support.
What connects us all is our passion for large format photography. Let’s unite as a community and support one another. Together we can promote the continued use of the large format camera.
About the ESC4P AIR Program
Our artist-in-residency is open to anyone shooting large format, film or digital. Each artist will submit an application, a portfolio, and a letter explaining their goals for a residency. Subject matter while participating is wholly artist-driven though there are some expectations on behalf of ESC4P.
The resident is expected to donate 2 prints to the organization and an additional print to be gifted to either the Southern Inyo Hospital (if the residency is in Lone Pine), or the Jerome Historical Society for Jerome residencies.
The artist is also expected to plan one event to share their work with the public within the community they select, either an informal lecture or a demonstration. He or she will be aided in this endeavor by ESC4P staff who will provide the venue and supporting logistics. The event will be video taped to share online for public education.
Upon completion of the residency, the artist’s work will be featured in View Camera Magazine. At least two images must be from the residency, preferably more. The work will also be showcased on our website. When enough residencies have been completed, the work will become part of a traveling exhibit.
To Sum Up
Our artist-in-residency is open to anyone shooting large format, film or digital.
The artist must:

Submit an application
Submit a portfolio
Submit a letter outlining his or her goals for the residency

The artist will receive:

A stipend of $1400 for covering expenses or, for artists with financial need, a scholarship of the stipend of $1400 + the cost of accommodation
Publication in View Camera Magazine (note that at least 2 images must be from the residency)
Work showcased on the ESC4P website
Participation in a traveling exhibit when enough residencies have been completed

The resident artist is expected to provide ESC4P the following:

Hold one public event, either a lecture or demonstration
This will be videotaped and shared online for public education
ESC4P staff will provide the support for venue, advertising, etc
Donate 2 prints from the residency
Donate 1 print to be gifted to a charitable organization in the residency area

For every dollar donated to our current fundraising campaign, 80 cents goes directly to funding. The 20% overhead covers the cost of perks, postage, and the administrative fee we pay to Fractured Atlas, our fiscal sponsor. Members of the Board of Directors receive only the cost of materials for any item they donate.

story:
Hello Friends!

 

Welcome to my wonderfully weird world. My name is Greg and I've been a professional photographer for over 10 years now. I've always been drawn to the strange and unusual. I enjoy experimenting with different styles and techniques, but my biggest passion is night photography and abandoned things. 5 years ago, I came up with a vague idea for an Alice in Wonderland themed shoot. After several months of planning, casting, and scouting, I was ready to take my first steps at capturing the ideas that had been in my head. My first shoot was the Mad Hatter. After that initial shoot, I knew I was onto something. I've spent the last 4 years and thousands of dollars of my own money bringing my creation to life. I've spent countless hours sewing all the costumes, scouting out locations, scouring antique stores, thrift stores, and e-bay for the perfect props and accessories to complete each scene. It's proven to be a much more difficult project than I originally anticipated due to the immensity of my vision and multiple setbacks. The project has already seen 3 recasts as models have moved away due to the long gaps between shoots. I've come to crowdfunding to help speed up the production cycle and complete my passion project.

 

So, what am I looking for? I believe I can complete this project with only $4,000. Where does that money go?

 

1. COSTUMES:

The largest portion of the money will be going towards completing the costumes. I still need to create several costumes for two of the larger group shots. The first shoot is for Rose and the flowers. The idea is, Rose will be dressed as a Victorian Madame with the flowers as colorful concubines. I'm talking corsets, hoop skirts, the whole shebang. The second shoot is for the card soldiers. My vision includes A Clockwork Orange-esque hooligans, but with more fetish wear.

 

2. UPGRADES:

As this project has grown in scale and interest, I've put more time and resources into each subsequent costume. A portion of the funding will go to upgrading and reworking earlier costumes to match the newer ones. Since multiple shoots have required recasting, some costumes or parts of them need to be resized and resewn entirely.

 

3. PROPS:

Your donations will also go to purchasing props and accessories to give the sets that extra pop.

 

4. TRANSPORTATION:

Since I mostly shoot in abandoned locations, I don’t require much money to pay for shooting locations. However, I will need to cover gas and other expenditures involved in getting the crew and props to and from destinations.

 

5. GALLERY EXHIBITION:

Another large portion of the funding goes toward renting wall space for a gallery exhibition as well as prints and frames for the show.

 

6. PERK FULFILLMENT:

As thanks for your donations, part of the proceeds will go towards offering prints of all my original work from my website www.noxvomica.com, and copies of the Alice book. Please see the perks section for more information.

 

While photography has been a huge part of my life for as long as I can remember, the progress I’ve made on this project has already spring boarded my career. Nothing makes my heart warmer than seeing the look of amazement in someone’s eyes when they view a shot I spent hours painstakingly setting up. I knew after only a year or two of working on the Alice project that there was a large chance that I’d need to turn to crowdfunding to finish it, but it was incredibly important to me to put everything I could into it. I’m not the type of person who asks for help, but I do believe fully in the power of art to enrich lives. I've put a lot of time and effort into these shoots already, so regardless of whether I meet my fundraising goal, I will be finishing this project.

 

I know not everyone can afford to donate, but if you’ve read this far and you like what you’ve seen, then please consider helping me by spreading the word to as many people as possible!

 

And lastly I want to give a big shout out, and thank you for everyone over the last 4 years who has helped with this project. My models Victor, Tammy, David W., Benjamin, Agustin, Renee, David J., and Nathan, and the absolute biggest thanks to Edwin. My makeup artist who has been crushing it from day one.  also thanks to Shawn, Dana, Aaron, Jay, Joshua, Kyros. For lending me things, getting me places. and giving me the start and push i needed.

story:
Hi all.

I am an artist / photographer dedicated to erotica and nude photography, living in Spain. As an artist, looking for my photography and explores the personal and human lafo photographed each girl, and fled perched those that do not reflect the reality of each. I do not use Photoshop to edit the image because I believe in pure photography, but shooting in digital. My specialty is black and white, but I shot some photos in color.

In Spain it is not as yet accepted this style of photography, there is a taboo on the nude and is quite difficult to break through the sole aim of erotic photography. But it is my dream, I think much of my work and photography as art, and my principles will not let me leave what fills me: eroticism.

Fortunately I've done a couple of exhibitions in Art Galleries. In my personal website you can see my artwork, my gallery, curriculum, and read my reviews of art (in Spanish). My photos have also been in some International Art Fairs (in Europe). Website: http://rauldap.weebly.com

Unfortunately, even a dream that did not allow me to live and invest in my work. My camera, a DSLR semi-professional, is giving me many problems and sometimes does not shoot, making it very difficult affects my concentration and my creativity, and consequently, the desire to take pictures decreases and the quality is affected ...

Buying a better DSLR is a very large and important expense that I can not afford, so I decided to create this campaign, but to acquire not the camera that I would like, but a smaller one with a decent quality, which allows me receive orders and to keep creating until you can save money for superior photographic equipment on my own.

Through this platform only ask for 800€ to buy the camera that allows me to continue to create and send the rewards.

I would be very happy if I get to the goal, because it's really hard for a young artist who started from the ground up without support to try to fulfill the dream of being someone in the art world.

Sorry for my poor english (Google translation helped me) and Thank you all!

story:
A little History about the man, and how we can help...

 Johnny Crash is more than a photographer: he is an historian documenting the shimmering world of modern burlesque. Since 2008 Mr. Crash has been on a furious tear to document the burlesque scene, and offers gorgeous-gammed gals and boisterous boys alike stunning and dramatic images to promote their craft.  His dedication to covering the scene is so complete, that on any given night, you're sure to run into him at one of the Bay Area's many burlesque shows.  Looking out from the stage as you’re giving the audience a coy look or a saucy wink, you can count on seeing his tower of hair behind the lens. Sadly, his camera isn’t keeping up with the furious pace Mr. Crash maintains. Just like money can’t buy you love, love can’t buy you cameras. But money can certainly buy cameras. Let’s help Johnny Crash continue capturing us on "film"!

Kitty VonQuimm

What will your money be doing for Mr. Crash?

All monies raised by this campain will be going directly towards replacing his, well loved, current DSLR. Allowing Mr. Crash to continue to follow his passion, further his vision and provide fabulous images to the performers he so admires.

Any funds raised beyond the goal will be put towards equipment that would broaden his photographic possibilities.

What will you receive for helping one of the Bay Areas most loved Photogs?

Pledge $25 or more      A signed 5x7 photograph by Johnny Crash

Pledge $100 or more    A 1-hour photo shoot with Johnny Crash

Pledge $150 or more    Photographic coverage of the event of your choice for up to three hours.

Pledge $200 or more    A framed and signed 11x14 photograph by Johnny Crash and the featured performer. (4 available)

Pledge $450 or more    A framed and signed 16x20 photograph by Johnny Crash and the featured performer. (4 available)


"What else can I do yo help?"

If you are unable to contribute finacially, don't forget you can always share this on your Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, personal blog or website. Hey ya can even spread the word with your friends over coffee!

story:
(ENGLISH version under the photographs)

¡ÚNETE A MAMBO!

¿Qué es Mambo#2?
Mambo#2 es el segundo volumen impreso nacido de la revista digital del mismo nombre. Siguiendo la filosofía de nuestro proyecto, Mambo#2 reúne en sus páginas a once excelentes fotógrafos de diferentes países, culturas, edades y estilos, para mostrar su obra tal como es, sin caer en detalles técnicos, ni grandes alardes de diseño, ni consideraciones que vayan más allá de la fotografía misma.

Así pues, Mambo#2, más que un libro de fotografía es un libro de fotógrafos. Y de sus obras. Es un reconocimiento al trabajo de los fotógrafos ya consagrados que aparecen en él, de la misma manera que esperamos sea un impulso para los jóvenes talentos con quienes comparten estas páginas.

Mambo#2 también es –o esperamos que sea– un libro inspirador y un placer para todos los amantes de la fotografía y todos aquellos que quieran perderse en las historias que surgen de sus imágenes.

¿Quiénes son los fotógrafos que saldrán en Mambo#2?
Como una imagen vale más que mil palabras (y más hablando de fotografía), ponemos más abajo los nombres de los once fotógrafos seleccionados, acompañados de una de sus fotos.

¿Por qué comprar una versión impresa de Mambo, si la versión online ya funciona?
Porque, a pesar de la tremenda importancia que ha adquirido Internet en la vida de todos, creemos firmemente que la fotografía, para ser disfrutada plenamente, tiene que estar impresa sobre un buen papel, que se pueda tocar, sentir y conservar. Además, estarás apoyando a que los fotógrafos publicados en Mambo sean reconocidos en todo el mundo, sin mencionar que este libro es una opción asequible para los amantes de la fotografía y de los libros de fotografía que existen.  

¿Existirá una versión digital de Mambo#2?
Existirá una versión digital únicamente como reward para quienes apoyen esta campaña de crowdfunding. No colgaremos en Internet ninguna versión digital de Mambo#2, como no lo hicimos tampoco del volumen anterior.

¿Las fotos de Mambo#2 han salido ya publicadas en la versión digital?
Algunas sí; otras, han sido cedidas por los fotógrafos expresamente para este libro.

¿En que idioma está Mambo?
Al igual que el primer volumen, Mambo#2 es una edición bilingüe castellano/inglés.

Me interesa vuestro proyecto pero no sé inglés y no entiendo qué es cada "perk".
Los perks estipulan lo que cada colaborador recibe a cambio del dinero que aporta. Puedes ver una versión traducida de éstas en nuestro website, clicando aquí. También se incluye el precio aproximado de cada perks en euros.

¿Cómo es Mambo#2, físicamente hablando?
Mambo#2 es un volumen de 19 x 27 cm y 124 páginas, diseñado e impreso con el máximo cuidado sobre papel estucado arte de 135g.

¿Por qué necesitáis 15.000 dólares (unos 11.800€)?
Los gastos de diseño y pre-impresión los tenemos cubiertos. De los 15.000 US$, aproximadamente 800 son para pagar las pruebas de color, 8.700 son para los costes de impresión, 200 para realizar la versión digital, unos 3.000 para la distribución y los 2300 restantes son para cubrir los gastos del crowdfunding, las tarifas bancarias y posibles (y probables) gastos imprevistos.

 

John Kenny

 

Sara Berihuete

 

Francisco Mata Rosas

 

Neil Craver

 

Mimí Mitsou

 

Marcos Osorio

 

Edwin S. Freyer

 

Mariana Palova

 

Sergio Murria

 

Tallyton Alves

 

Óscar Vázquez Chambó

 

ENGLISH TEXT

JOIN MAMBO!

What is Mambo#2?
Mambo#2 is the second hardcopy issue developed from the digital magazine  of the same name. According to the philosophy of our project, Mambo#2 compiles the work of eleven excellent photographers from different countries, cultures, ages and styles, displaying their photographs in their main essence, without technology gadgets, "wonderful" exhibitions of graphic design or any other aspect that may go beyond photography itself.

So, Mambo#2, is not really a photography book, but a book about photographers. And about their work. It's an acknowledgement to the older, well recognized photographers that appear in its pages, as much as it's an attempt to support the careers of the young talents who appear in this book.  

Mambo#2 is also –or so we hope– an inspirational book and a pleasure to photography lovers and to everyone willing to get lost in the stories told by its images.

Which photographers are featured in Mambo#2?
You can look above to find the names of the eleven photographers featured in the book, along with one of their photographs. Also, be sure to visit mambomag.com to find more information about them. 

Why should I pay for a hardcopy version of Mambo, when the online one is pretty nice already?
Mambo #2  is an affordable alternative to the very expensive photography books out there and we strongly believe to fully enjoy photography, it must be printed on a good paper, one you can touch, feel and keep. Aside from that, you will be making it possible for many photographers to be recognized and known all over the world, no to mention there's no advertising in its pages, nothing that could take your eyes the photographs themselves. 

Will you launch a digital version of Mambo#2?

We will launch a digital version of Mambo#2 exclusively as a reward for the backers of this project. We won't upload to the Internet any digital version of Mambo#2, as we didn't with the previous issue.

Have the photographs showed in Mambo#2  already been published in the digital version of the magazine?
Some were; many others have been sent by their authors just to be published in the hardcopy book.

In which language is Mambo#2?
Like the first issue, Mambo#2 is a bilingual edition, English/Spanish.

How is Mambo#2, physically?
Mambo#2 is 7,5 x 11 inches, 124 pages, designed and printed with the best care and quality on 135g bright coated paper.

Why do you need 15.000 USD (around 11.800€)?
We already have covered the design and pre-press expenses. From those $15,000, we need approximately $800 to pay the color proofs, $8.700 for the printer, $200 for the digital version, 3,000 for the distribution and the other $2300 for the crowdfunding and bank expenses, as well as possible (and probable) unexpected expenses.
story_txt:
(ENGLISH version under the photographs)
¡ÚNETE A MAMBO!
¿Qué es Mambo#2?Mambo#2 es el segundo volumen impreso nacido de la revista digital del mismo nombre. Siguiendo la filosofía de nuestro proyecto, Mambo#2 reúne en sus páginas a once excelentes fotógrafos de diferentes países, culturas, edades y estilos, para mostrar su obra tal como es, sin caer en detalles técnicos, ni grandes alardes de diseño, ni consideraciones que vayan más allá de la fotografía misma.
Así pues, Mambo#2, más que un libro de fotografía es un libro de fotógrafos. Y de sus obras. Es un reconocimiento al trabajo de los fotógrafos ya consagrados que aparecen en él, de la misma manera que esperamos sea un impulso para los jóvenes talentos con quienes comparten estas páginas.
Mambo#2 también es –o esperamos que sea– un libro inspirador y un placer para todos los amantes de la fotografía y todos aquellos que quieran perderse en las historias que surgen de sus imágenes.
¿Quiénes son los fotógrafos que saldrán en Mambo#2?Como una imagen vale más que mil palabras (y más hablando de fotografía), ponemos más abajo los nombres de los once fotógrafos seleccionados, acompañados de una de sus fotos.
¿Por qué comprar una versión impresa de Mambo, si la versión online ya funciona?Porque, a pesar de la tremenda importancia que ha adquirido Internet en la vida de todos, creemos firmemente que la fotografía, para ser disfrutada plenamente, tiene que estar impresa sobre un buen papel, que se pueda tocar, sentir y conservar. Además, estarás apoyando a que los fotógrafos publicados en Mambo sean reconocidos en todo el mundo, sin mencionar que este libro es una opción asequible para los amantes de la fotografía y de los libros de fotografía que existen.  
¿Existirá una versión digital de Mambo#2?Existirá una versión digital únicamente como reward para quienes apoyen esta campaña de crowdfunding. No colgaremos en Internet ninguna versión digital de Mambo#2, como no lo hicimos tampoco del volumen anterior.
¿Las fotos de Mambo#2 han salido ya publicadas en la versión digital?Algunas sí; otras, han sido cedidas por los fotógrafos expresamente para este libro.
¿En que idioma está Mambo?Al igual que el primer volumen, Mambo#2 es una edición bilingüe castellano/inglés.
Me interesa vuestro proyecto pero no sé inglés y no entiendo qué es cada "perk".Los perks estipulan lo que cada colaborador recibe a cambio del dinero que aporta. Puedes ver una versión traducida de éstas en nuestro website, clicando aquí. También se incluye el precio aproximado de cada perks en euros.
¿Cómo es Mambo#2, físicamente hablando?Mambo#2 es un volumen de 19 x 27 cm y 124 páginas, diseñado e impreso con el máximo cuidado sobre papel estucado arte de 135g.
¿Por qué necesitáis 15.000 dólares (unos 11.800€)?Los gastos de diseño y pre-impresión los tenemos cubiertos. De los 15.000 US$, aproximadamente 800 son para pagar las pruebas de color, 8.700 son para los costes de impresión, 200 para realizar la versión digital, unos 3.000 para la distribución y los 2300 restantes son para cubrir los gastos del crowdfunding, las tarifas bancarias y posibles (y probables) gastos imprevistos.
 
John Kenny

 
Sara Berihuete

 
Francisco Mata Rosas

 
Neil Craver

 
Mimí Mitsou

 
Marcos Osorio

 
Edwin S. Freyer

 
Mariana Palova

 
Sergio Murria

 
Tallyton Alves

 
Óscar Vázquez Chambó

story:
First of all, let me introduce myself:

I’m Manaure Quintero, a freelance photojournalist born and based in Caracas, Venezuela, a country that’s facing the hardest crisis in its history: highest inflation in the world, the highest murder rate in recent years, and a political confrontation that affects socially and economically; malnutrition, violence in many ways, the collapse of the health system and corruption. Through my work I look to denounce these terrible situations, it´s my way to show to the world the things that are happening in my country, where working as a journalist is one of the most difficult jobs to do.

A riot police officer pulls a protester during a demonstration in Caracas, Venezuela.

 

It has been my work in Venezuela the reason I have been selected from more than 2900 applicants to participate in the Fifth New York Portfolio Review, organized by The New York Times and the City University of New York Graduate School of Journalism, where the most important editors from the United States and Europe from the most recognized medias, galleries, museums, and many others, can check my work personally and possibly get future working opportunities to continue to  push my career and my message.

This amazing opportunity came alongside two invitations made by important institutions: Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Boston, I was invited to speak about my work covering the collapse of Venezuela’s health system and the impact in recent and old virus as Zika, Malaria.

Karla 16 (L) and Aurelys (R) help his mother Ingrid Castellanos (C), a 40 years old domestic worker from Cararacas who have cervical cancer that turns in metastasis two months earlier. Aurelys (18) left her civil construction studies as well as her maintenance work in the weekends to stay and help her mother during her sickness.

 

These three events represent a great opportunity, not only in a personal aspect but also to share and spread knowledge and awareness to the situation in my country around the world.

Unfortunately, and as a consequence of the hard economical situation in Venezuela I have not the necessary funds to afford this journey, and that’s why I hope to reach this goal with your support.

Two children receive a beverage from an know women when she saw them looking for food in the trash of Coche’s public market in Caracas, Venezuela.

 

To afford plane tickets, housing, feeding and transportation expenses during my time in Boston and New York City, places where those events are going to be held, the goal is to reach US$ 3000.

Every contribution will be a great support to my career as a photojournalist at the same time it would allow me to find new spaces in the media industry to show the struggle of my people in my homeland.

Rewards for your contribution:

If is not much what I can offer, this is what I would give you to those who support me on my goal:

$10 - Social network gratitude: Through my social networks you’ll receive my gratitude for your support.

$25 - Postcard (Digital): You will receive a signed postcard with a personal gratitude message on it. You will select them through my website or my Instagram account.

$50 - 4 Postcard (Digital): You will receive 2 signed postcards from my work in Venezuela and 2 from relevant places of New York and Boston with a personal gratitude message on it. You will select them through my website or my Instagram account.

$100 - E-Photobook: You will receive a E-Photobook with an edition of 20 exclusive images of my journey to New York and Boston, showing the most important and historic places of the city.

$200 - E-Photobook  and  Photochronicle: You will receive a E-Photobook with an edition of 25 exclusive images of my journey to New York and Boston, showing the most important and historic places of the city. As well as a Photochronicle of my journey, to show you the same the experience I lived during this important time of my life. Nobody except you as my supporter will have this unique piece!

Afghan children plays with water inside the self settled refugee camp in Pedion Areos park in Athens, Greece.

 

Other ways you can help:

Any contribution is important but you can also support me by sharing my campaign with your friends.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Mi nombre es Manaure Quintero y soy fotoperiodista freelance nacido y radicado en Caracas, Venezuela, un país que actualmente enfrenta la crisis más dura de su historia: una altísima inflación, la mayor tasa de asesinatos de los últimos años, una confrontación política que afecta social, económica y políticamente a los venezolanos, desnutrición, violencia en diferentes ámbitos, derrumbe del sistema de salud, corrupción... A través de mi trabajo fotográfico busco denunciar estas terribles situaciones, es la forma que tengo de mostrarle al mundo lo que sucede en mi país, a pesar de que se ha convertido en uno de los lugares más difíciles para ejercer el periodismo.

Members of the National Guard walk toward protesters during a demonstration against the government in Caracas, Venezuela.​

 

Ha sido precisamente mi trabajo en Venezuela, el que me ha llevado a ser seleccionado en el 5to. New York Portfolio Review, patrocinado por el New York Times Lens blog y the City University of New York Graduate School of Journalism, entre más de 2900 aplicantes, y donde los más importantes editores de medios de Estados Unidos y Europa podrán conocer y revisar mi portafolio fotográfico, y así obtener oportunidades laborales a futuro e impulsar mi carrera.

Mi selección en este evento coincide además con dos invitaciones que me hicieran importantes instituciones: la Universidad de Harvard y el Masashussets Institute of Tecnology en Boston, donde fui invitado a dar una clase y una charla informativa, respectivamente, sobre los índices de Zika, Malaria y otros virus en Venezuela.

An Aedes Aegypti mosquito bite a hand inside the insectarium laboratory in the Venezuelan Institute of Scientis Investigation in Caracas, Venezuela.

 

Estos 3 eventos representan una gran oportunidad, no sólo a manera personal y profesional, si no que además, me permitirán dar a conocer los diferentes problemas que actualmente padecemos en nuestro país.

Desafortunadamente, y como consecuencia de la situación económica venezolana, no cuento con los recursos necesarios para poder asistir a estos eventos, es por ello que con el apoyo de todos ustedes, busco alcanzar esta meta.  

People from Tumeremo, Venezuela; cries the lost of their relatives, killed by criminals who controls de main gold mines in south Venezuela.

 

Para costear los boletos áereos, el alojamiento, los gastos de alimentación y transporte durante mi estancia en Nueva York y Boston, donde se desarrollaran estos eventos en los que he sido seleccionado e invitado, mi meta es conseguir 3000 $.

Cada contribución será un gran apoyo a mi carrera como fotoperiodista y al mismo tiempo permitirá encontrar nuevos espacios en los medios de comunicación internacionales para denunciar las dificultades de un país en una profunda crisis.

Recompensas:

Si bien es poco lo que puedo ofrecer, esto es lo que daría con mucha gratitud a quienes me ayuden a cumplir la meta:

10 dólares - Agradecimientos especiales: A través de mis redes sociales y mi página web, recibirás un saludo especial por tu aporte. 

25 dólares - Foto postal: Recibirás una foto postal digital que podrás seleccionar tú mismo desde mi página web o mi cuenta Instagram. 
 

50 dólares - 4 Fotos postales: Recibirás 2  fotos postales de mi trabajo en Venezuela y 2 de lugares emblemáticos de Nueva York y Boston que haré durante mi viaje a estos eventos, que podrás seleccionar desde mi página web o mi cuenta Instagram.  

100 dólares - Fotolibro digital: Recibirás un Fotolibro digital con una selección exclusiva de 20 fotos de mi viaje por Nueva York o Boston. 
 

200 dólares - Fotolibro y Fotocrónica digital: Recibirás un Fotolibro digital con 25 fotos de Nueva York y Boston. Y además un Fotocrónica digital con fotografías e historias únicas y exclusivas de mi viaje, que sólo tú como patrocinante obtendrás ya que no serán publicadas en ningún otro sitio, lo que te brindara la experiencia de vivir conmigo este increíble momento. 

A teenager carries an 80kg bag of carrots in the rural area of Pueblo Llano, Venezuela; many children and teenagers from the rural areas of Venezuela have left the school to help their family on the home expenses.

 

Puedes ayudar de otras formas:

Cualquier contribución es importante pero también puedes apoyarme compartiendo mi campaña con tus amigos.

story:
ABOUT THE BOOK

The most ambitious, exciting winemakers in the world aren’t coming from Europe, or even Napa Valley. The focus of the wine world has turned to a former cow town that is now making the most coveted wines in the word: Paso Robles, California.

Many readers may have been introduced to the region in the Oscar®-winning movie “Sideways” (shot in nearby Santa Barbara County) . But for the last 20 years, ambitious winemakers have been making incredible, unique, delicious vintages that challenge everything we thought we knew about wine. They continue to turn the wine world on its head, and they're loving every minute of it.

 

My name is Julia Perez and I am a professional photographer from Argentina. I love wine and I am fascinated with winemakers. Over the last few years I have been fortunate to have taken photos of vineyards, wineries and winemakers all over the world. Last year I teamed up with legendary California wine writer Paul Hodgins and spent an entire vintage embedded with 50 of the most ambitious and influential winemakers and vintners in Paso Robles.

The result is "The Winemakers of Paso Robles", a large format, full-color book, lovingly crafted and designed to take you beyond the cellar door, deep into the art and science of making the finest wines in the world, and celebrating the men and women who dedicate their lives in this California region to the pursuit of liquid perfection.

 

Through nearly 300 pages, with hundreds of behind-the-scenes photographs and months of penetrating interviews, this journey into the world of Paso Robles winemaking provides an intimate glimpse into the passionate lives and unbelievable stories of the people behind Paso’s vibrant wine community – whose vision, talent and audacity have helped make it one of the world’s most exciting wine regions.

Specifications:

  • Hardcover: Embossed Linen 
  • 11 x 14.5 inches Portrait
  • ~300 pages
  • French-fold jacket   
  • MSRP $119

 

 

EVERY WINEMAKER & VINTNER HAS A STORY

An accidental meeting, a change of circumstances, an influential person or even a bolt from the blue in the middle of the night. Everyone has their own path that led them to a life of winemaking - a balance of art and science, physically demanding and mentally strenuous - lives of passion, and pursuit, and struggle.

To a winemaker, every vintage is its own discrete labor of love. A game of 3-dimensional chess against the elements, coaxing the perfect balance from the sun, the soil, rain and vine. If they get any one of a thousand decisions wrong, the vintage can be ruined and they have to wait another year to try again. But get it just right, and they’ve created magic in a glass.

In these pages you will meet a group of fascinating, passionate people, with amazing diversity. Athletes and scientists, writers and engineers, successful businessmen and scrappy service workers. There are journeymen from every corner of the country, and even legendary wine regions of the old world. And of course there are local kids done good. There are seasoned pros and relative neophytes - and several on their second, or even third career. Many overcame tremendous adversity. All have made enormous sacrifices and risked everything.

They have come from different places and circumstances, they have different methods and experiences and philosophies. But they all share a single quality: a burning obsession to make wine that lives up to their dreams.

OUR WINEMAKERS & VINTNERS

Each of the following subjects is profiled in detail in the book. Learn their stories and see them at work making some of the best wines in the world:

• Adeliada Vineyards & Winery : Jeremy Weintraub 

• Alta Colina : Bob Tillman 

• AmByth Estate : Phillip Hart 

• Anarchy Wines : Christian Tietje

• Anglim Winery : Stephen Anglim

• Booker Wines : Eric Jensen 

• Castoro Cellars : Niels Udsen

• Chateau Margene : Michael Mooney

• Chronic Cellars : Josh Beckett

story_txt:
ABOVE: Rendering of the book
 
ABOUT THE BOOK
The most ambitious, exciting winemakers in the world aren’t coming from Europe, or even Napa Valley. The focus of the wine world has turned to a former cow town that is now making the most coveted wines in the word: Paso Robles, California.
Many readers may have been introduced to the region in the Oscar®-winning movie “Sideways” (shot in nearby Santa Barbara County) . But for the last 20 years, ambitious winemakers have been making incredible, unique, delicious vintages that challenge everything we thought we knew about wine. They continue to turn the wine world on its head, and they're loving every minute of it.
ABOVE: Dust jacket front & back
 
My name is Julia Perez and I am a professional photographer from Argentina. I love wine and I am fascinated with winemakers. Over the last few years I have been fortunate to have taken photos of vineyards, wineries and winemakers all over the world. Last year I teamed up with legendary California wine writer Paul Hodgins and spent an entire vintage embedded with 50 of the most ambitious and influential winemakers and vintners in Paso Robles.
The result is "The Winemakers of Paso Robles", a large format, full-color book, lovingly crafted and designed to take you beyond the cellar door, deep into the art and science of making the finest wines in the world, and celebrating the men and women who dedicate their lives in this California region to the pursuit of liquid perfection.
 
ABOVE: Interior Pages - Introduction
 
Through nearly 300 pages, with hundreds of behind-the-scenes photographs and months of penetrating interviews, this journey into the world of Paso Robles winemaking provides an intimate glimpse into the passionate lives and unbelievable stories of the people behind Paso’s vibrant wine community – whose vision, talent and audacity have helped make it one of the world’s most exciting wine regions.
Specifications:

Hardcover: Embossed Linen 
11 x 14.5 inches Portrait
~300 pages
French-fold jacket   
MSRP $119

 
ABOVE: See book size in scale
 
ABOVE: Interior Pages - Stephan Asseo
 
EVERY WINEMAKER & VINTNER HAS A STORY
An accidental meeting, a change of circumstances, an influential person or even a bolt from the blue in the middle of the night. Everyone has their own path that led them to a life of winemaking - a balance of art and science, physically demanding and mentally strenuous - lives of passion, and pursuit, and struggle.
To a winemaker, every vintage is its own discrete labor of love. A game of 3-dimensional chess against the elements, coaxing the perfect balance from the sun, the soil, rain and vine. If they get any one of a thousand decisions wrong, the vintage can be ruined and they have to wait another year to try again. But get it just right, and they’ve created magic in a glass.
Interior Pages - Stephan Asseo
 
In these pages you will meet a group of fascinating, passionate people, with amazing diversity. Athletes and scientists, writers and engineers, successful businessmen and scrappy service workers. There are journeymen from every corner of the country, and even legendary wine regions of the old world. And of course there are local kids done good. There are seasoned pros and relative neophytes - and several on their second, or even third career. Many overcame tremendous adversity. All have made enormous sacrifices and risked everything.
They have come from different places and circumstances, they have different methods and experiences and philosophies. But they all share a single quality: a burning obsession to make wine that lives up to their dreams.
OUR WINEMAKERS & VINTNERS
Each of the following subjects is profiled in detail in the book. Learn their stories and see them at work making some of the best wines in the world:

story:
The Project

"Surveillance Landscapes" is a series that I've been working on for two years. To produce this work, I tap into surveillance cameras, public webcams, and CCTV feeds around the world in pursuit of the “classical” picturesque landscape. The resulting visual product becomes dislocated from its automated origins and leads to an investigation of land, borders, and power. The surveillance state is totalizing in its global reach and we must look at how this effects us from all perspectives. Nevertheless, the very act of someone surveying a site through these photographic systems implies a dominating relationship between man and place.

I am working with Daylight books to produce a monograph of this work for publication in the spring of 2018. The costs will go directly to the editing, production, and distribution of  this book. This includes working with multiple editors on layout and design, multiple proofs, and the production of the book at a professional press.

Book Details 

  • Photographs: approx. 40-44 images 
  • Size: approx. 8 in x 11 in hardcover 
  • Edition: First run approx. 1000
  • Publication date: Spring 2018

About the artist:

Marcus DeSieno is a lens-based artist who is interested in how the advancement of photographic technology has changed our relationship to the natural world. DeSieno often combines antiquated and obsolescent photographic processes with contemporary imaging technologies to engage in a critical dialog on the evolution of the photographic medium in relation to seeing. He received his MFA in Studio Art from the University of South Florida and is currently the Visiting Professor of Photography at Marlboro College in Marlboro, Vermont.

DeSieno's work has been exhibited nationally at The Center for Fine Art Photography, the Fort Wayne Museum of Art, The Light Factory, Candela Gallery, Rayko Photo Center, The Center for Photography at Woodstock, and various other galleries and museums. His work has also been featured in a variety of publications including FeatureShoot, GUP Magazine, Hyperallergic, Huffington Post, National Geographic's Proof, PDN, Slate, Smithsonian Magazine, and Wired. DeSieno was recently named a selection for Photolucida's Critical Mass 50 and an Emerging Talent by Lensculture for 2016.

About Daylight:

Daylight is a non-profit organization dedicated to publishing art and photography books. By exploring the documentary mode along with the more conceptual concerns of fine-art, Daylight’s uniquely collectible publications work to revitalize the relationship between art, photography, and the world-at-large. 

Risks and challenges:

The risks and challenges when publishing a photobook include the possibility of delay, but we are aiming for a release in early Spring of 2018. Daylight is a professional organization and we will do everything in our power to turn out the best possible product.

 

Please help to spread the word about this project by sharing this link with your contacts.   Thank you for your support! 

 

www.marcusdesieno.com

Recent Press: 

https://www.fastcompany.com/3067403/this-eerie-landscape-art-is-actually-hacked-surveillance-footage

https://www.wired.com/2017/02/surveillance-cams-everywhere-even-wilderness/

https://www.nzz.ch/feuilleton/foto-tableau-marcus-desieno-ld.147512​

https://fstoppers.com/spotlight/beautiful-landscapes-taken-comfort-computer-167042

story:
My name is David Goldman; I’m an award winning documentary and commercial photographer. Throughout my career I’ve had the incredible fortune to work on a wide variety of photo projects that have ranged from hyper-stylized album covers of musicians like Blink-182 to portraits of CBS’ 60 Minutes correspondents. 

Then there are the projects that are much closer to my heart like working for UN Women highlighting the struggles of violence against women in India & Bangladesh or being in Ethiopia and doing a story on obstetric fistula. The most personally rewarding projects are the ones that will bring attention to issues and causes that will resonate with the people that view them.

     

     

I invite you to join me on a new photo/video journey. This project will take place in India for one month beginning in mid November. During this time I will document how the commoditization of the sugar industry has adversely affected the Indian migrant worker, people who travel with their families from small outlying villages to larger factory towns and cities.

As large sugarcane factories are polluting once fertile land, politicians are looking the other way while underpaid and maltreated workers are contracting illnesses like chronic kidney disease (CKD). HIV continues to spread while the worker’s job related neglect of their parents and children can damage a family irreparably.  I will travel by oxcart with migrant workers from their villages to the factory towns, learning along the way what motivates them and what are the challenges they face both individually and as families. Once they begin to work I will accompany them in the fields and document on film and video what it means to be a sugarcane factory worker, it’s risks and it’s meager rewards.

In my many travels there is one thing I have found to be true which is that every family wants to do the best for its children, to make a better life. But that can mean many different things depending on the family, from higher education to food and shelter but the motivation that drives them is always the same: a better life for their children.

We are constantly being inundated with images of horror, pain and suffering. In time this can become visual white noise. We tune out and the impact is no longer felt and then so often we stop caring. My feeling is that there is more to be accomplished by showing positive and inclusive imagery than divisive and controversial ones which often leave us feeling helpless and depressed. I try hard in my work to show the positive, knowing full well and disappointingly it’s not always possible.

How you can help

Your generous contributions will help me travel to India to document and share this story.  I will be able to cover the cost of rental gear, lodging, editing of photos and video as well as creating a multi-media website that will help spread the message throughout the world. A powerful story can help raise awareness and contributions that can go to more education so that we can all make better informed decisions.

Other Ways You Can Help

I completely understand that financial realities don't always allow for actual monetary contributions and if that's the situation you're in, you can still help by posting this campaign on your social media pages and giving me a boost to get the word out. A good thought and positive wishes can go a long way! 

The back story

In Ethiopia I did a story about two young women who suffered the devastating consequences of obstetric fistula and as a result lost their babies at childbirth. Both young women were left incontinent and alone in their huts. Helping them to reunite with their families after successful surgery was one of the most rewarding experiences of my life.

Thanks to the work I produced in Ethiopia, the United Nations Trust Fund To End Violence Against Women hired me to go to India and Bangladesh to produce four stories and report back about how the UN’s money was being put to use. I covered different aspects of violence against women including dowry related issues, sex workers, migrant workers and the challenges of aboriginal Indians known as Adivasi.

While on this project with UN Women and on the way to a remote village to talk to a group of sex workers we drove by a sugarcane factory and I was astonished by what I saw. It was a tent city in the shadow of a huge factory complex. I asked the driver to stop so I could go interact with some of the people there.  It was during this twenty minute stop that I saw some disturbing things.

I learned that these migrant workers harvest the sugarcane from around November through March each year. The workers often travel for a few days on ox carts to get to the factory. Often they will bring their entire family including children and the elders. It is this whole family unit that sets up in the tent city and remains there while the harvesting continues.

The work is both backbreaking and dangerous and the days are long.  At the end of it all there’s a real possibility that due to corruption the workers may not get paid what they're owed. Yet they travel from a far because they need to provide for their families with the hope of a better life.

Knowing that at any given time at any place on this earth there are stories that can be shared that will inspire, inform and educate, my mission is to document and shed light on these stories. To me that is what being a photographer is all about. I welcome your support.

Thank you!

David

Facebook     Website     Instagram     Twitter     Blog
